From Oscar winning director Frank Capra (The Bitter Tea of General Yen, Mr. Deeds Goes to Town, Mr. Smith Goes to Washington, It's a Wonderful Life), this was the first film to win "the Big 5" awards at the Oscars (a record equalled by One Flew over the Cuckoo's Nest and The Silence of the Lambs). Basically Ellen "Ellie" Andrews (Oscar winning Claudette Colbert) is a spoiled heiress who, despite the objections of her wealthy father Alexander (Walter Connolly), is eloped to pilot and fortune-hunter "King" Westley (Jameson Thomas), the father wants the marriage annulled as he knows Westley only wants her money. In Florida, Ellie jumps ship and runs away, boarding a bus to New York City, she wants to reunite with King, on the journey she meets freshly out-of-work newspaper reporter Peter Warne (Oscar winning Clark Gable), they initially start with some seemingly coincidental bumping into each other. Peter recognises Ellie and gives her a choice: give him an exclusive story and he will help her, or he will tell her father where she is, she agrees to the first option. Peter and Ellie go through several adventures together, her initial disdain for him fades away, she finds herself falling in love with him, there is a point when she uses her sex appeal to get a hitchhike, but the person who picks them up attempts to steal their luggage, but Peter stop him, and steals his car. Nearing the end of their journey, Ellie confesses her love for Peter, the next morning Peter has disappeared, believing he has deserted her Ellie calls her father, who agrees to let her marry Westley, Peter meanwhile has obtained money from his editor to marry Ellie. Ellie has no desire to be with Westley, but she believes Peter has betrayed her for the reward money, a second formal wedding to Westley goes ahead, on her wedding day Ellie finally reveals everything, Peter comes to her family home where her father offers him the reward money, but only insists on being paid his expenses. Peter explains his odd behaviour to Ellie's father is due to the fact that he admits his love for her, Westley arrives for his wedding via an autogyro, but at the ceremony Mr. Andrews reveals Peter's refusal to take the reward money to Ellie, he sends her to Peter, and pays Westley off, Peter and Ellie offscreen finally embrace. Also starring Roscoe Karns as Oscar Shapeley, Alan Hale as Danker, Arthur Hoyt as Zeke, Blanche Friderici as Zeke's wife and Charles C. Wilson as Joe Gordon. Gable is very likable as the good looking hard-nosed reporter who lightens up, Colbert is pretty and amusing as the runaway heiress who realises true happiness, together they are a great duo and partnership. I previously admitted that I didn't understand this film very well, however watching it again it is fairly straight forward, it is well written with good funny lines and mishaps, and classy and charming performances and interactions, it certainly deserves its status as a classic romantic comedy. It won the Oscars for Best Picture and Best Writing, Adaptation. Clarke Gable number 63 on The 100 Greatest Movie Stars, he was also number 7 on 100 Years, 100 Stars - Men, the film was number 38 on 100 Years, 100 Passions, and it was number 35 on 100 Years, 100 Movies. Very good!

reviews.review_title: Can't be blamed for what it has started.
reviews.content: Romantic comedy is one of the most fun of all movie genres; a great one is mixed with a nice balance of romance and humor that is very enjoyable for the actors and the audience. Today, these "rom-coms" are much more cynical and bitter; almost to a point of not being funny or romantic at all. They also so rigidly follow a formula that it becomes incredibly difficult to find any part of the story that is surprising, refreshing or even remotely entertaining.Here is a film that very well may be the first example of what is considered a romantic comedy. Often called the first screwball comedy, this is anything but for there are very few fast-talking dialog scenes and the on-screen couple don't get into too crazy of situations. Directed with down-to-earth sincerity by that great American director, Frank Capra, the story of a spoiled young woman taken from her high society settings and stuck with a wise-cracking, handsome man who takes her under his wing and sets her straight is as old as the hills. And yet, it works here effortlessly due mostly to the wonderful and realistic chemistry between the two lead actors.Clark Gable and Claudette Colbert, two of the biggest stars in Hollywood at the time, reportedly both disliked the script and only did it for money and steady work. Neither would have thought that an Oscar for each and huge acclaim was waiting for them on the other side. Each actor's personality complemented the other perfectly; Gable's smart-ass remarks and smug grins against Colbert's soft, delicate yet independent facial expressions. Another element here handled much better than today is the parental issue. For most parents in these movies, they are either blithering idiots with no mind for parenting or bull-whipping tyrants with no evident love for their children's welfare. Here, the father is a little hard but is certainly filled with love and only wants what is best for his daughter.Still, perhaps this film will live one forever because of the incredibly smart and funny script. Based on a short story, screenwriter Robert Riskin fleshed out the characters and threw in some really great one-liners revealing not only the conflict between the main characters, but also the features and mannerisms that would put them in future situations. Nearly every scene is wonderful to watch unfold. The great timing between Gable and Colbert adds to the snappy dialog and makes the watching all the more enjoyable.It is amazing what has happened to practically every part of the great medium that is film a mere 80 years later. What was once great comedy and great romance together in the same story today turns into wild and illicit sex or stupid, dumbed down physical comedy and cheap laughs. Sometimes they have both; but here it comes down to well-written and acted characters along with two very likable actors letting their personas shine and the story do the talking. It really is true when they say they just don't make them like they used to.

This is the Best comedy/romance ever written, it is a must see for film buffs. This movie helped me realize why Clark Cable was so popular in his day, and claudette colbert is perfect at the spoiled daughter trying to run from her father.

NOTES: Best Picture (defeating an especially strong and varied line- up: The Barretts of Wimpole Street, Cleopatra, Flirtation Walk, The Gay Divorcée, Here Comes the Navy, The House of Rothschild, Imitation of Life, One Night of Love, The Thin Man, Viva Villa and The White Parade).Best Actor, Clark Gable (defeating Frank Morgan in Affairs of Cellini and William Powell in The Thin Man). Best Actress, Claudette Colbert (defeating Grace Moore in One Night of Love, Norma Shearer in The Barretts of Wimpole Street and Bette Davis in Of Human Bondage). (Davis was not officially nominated but received a significant number of write-in votes).Best Directing, Frank Capra (defeating Victor Schertzinger for One Night of Love, and W. S. Van Dyke for The Thin Man).Best Adapted Screenplay (defeating The Thin Man and Viva Villa).Best Picture of 1934 — Mordaunt Hall in The New York Times.3rd Best Film of 1934 (after The Barretts of Wimpole Street and The House of Rothschild) — a poll of U.S. film critics conducted by The Film Daily. Best Film of 1934 — Picturegoer (London), a magazine that also selected Clark Gable as the year's Best Actor.Re-made (unofficially) as Eve Knew Her Apples (1945); and (officially) as You Can't Run Away From It (1956).COMMENT: Holds up amazingly well, thanks largely to Capra's inspired direction. After an uncertain start with a shipboard scene between Colbert and Connolly that seems a little strained, the pace picks up (and never stops) as soon as Gable enters. Both Gable and Colbert deserved their acting awards — especially Gable who was never in better physical or charismatic form and certainly never equaled his spirited yet delightfully amusing performance in this movie. (There's even an astonishing Preston Sturges-like sequence in which Gable is hailed as "the King"). The support cast is equally adept. Technical credits, including Joseph Walker's superb photography, are impeccable.Dick Powell's 1956 re-make has none of the charm or the bizarre comedy of the original. It Happened One Night is very much a film of its time — impossible to up-date without losing its special yet entirely credible zaniness.AVAILABLE on a excellent Sony DVD.

In the mid-1930's when Hollywood decided to enforce the production code, movies really got cleaned up. Tales of street life disappeared, movies dropped the sly lines of innuendo, and even the monster movies weren't so monstery anymore. It was a great time for romantic comedies where everything worked out in the end. While most of them were forgettable, "It Happened One Night" is memorable for many reasons.As much as being a story about a man and woman falling in love despite themselves and despite the efforts of family and business to intervene on both sides, the movie is a record of the time - a time of traveling by bus through the night, a time of hitchhiking with pleasure and with confidence, and a time when newspaper deadlines still mattered, at least to the newspapers.Hundreds of reviews mention that this movie swept the top five Oscar categories, but that's never the most reliable gauge of a movie's worth. Only seeing it can really show you what's to like about a movie - the characters, the performances, the lasting mood of its moments of fun and moments of melancholy."It Happened One Night" doesn't waste space. Each scene contributes something to the film's character. The irreverent sarcasm between the leads constantly builds the tongue in cheek tone. The moderately-paced plot keeps interest without skipping too fast across the light parts of the story. The unlikable nature of the leads dissolves as we see enough their characters to appreciate the hidden chemistry between them.

In Summer 1933, Columbia Pictures paid $5000 for the rights to "Night Bus," a short story written by Samuel Hopkins Adams that appeared in the August version of Cosmopolitan.  After completion of the film Lady for a Day, director Frank Capra and screenwriter Robert Riskin began work on the film adaptation; as several bus-related films had recently failed at the box office, they changed the title to It Happened One Night.Columbia, a small studio with few stars under contract, made it a company policy to borrow expensive name-brand talent "as needed."  So when Capra wanted MGM's Robert Montgomery and Myrna Loy for It Happened One Night, Columbia's prsident, Harry Cohn, sent the script to their boss, Louis B. Mayer.  Although both stars were unavailable, Mayer surprised Cohn when he insisted Columbia take MGM's top leading man, Clark Gable, instead.With Gable confirmed, Capra turned to the casting of his female lead role. After Miriam Hopkins, Margaret Sullivan and Constance Bennett turned him down, Capra approached Paramount's Claudette Colbert, who didn't want to play the heiress role either.  Instead of saying no, however, the actress made Capra an offer she was sure would be rejected: $50,000 for four weeks work.  To Colbert's amazement, Cohn agreed to her terms.Production of the $225,000 project began on November 13, 1933.  Although Gable was intially reluctant to work on It Happened One Night, he soon warmed up to Capra and gave a charming performance, one that would forever cement his screen image as a breezy, good-natured man of the world. Colbert, however, was another story.  Although she gave an Oscar-winning performance, the actress did not want to make the film and continued to give Capra a difficult time throughout production.  After her scenes were completed, Colbert went on vacation to Sun Valley, where she told friends, "I've just finished the worst picture in the world."It Happened One Night was released on February 23, 1934, to moderate to indifferent reviews.  But audiences across the country adored the film and made it the sleeper hit of the year.  The first screwball comedy (before Bringing Up Baby), It Happened One Night went on to sweep the Academy Awards, winning all five major Oscars that it had been nominated for: Best Picture, Best Director, Best Actor, Best Actress and Best Screenplay.  But it was Claudette Colbert who knew exactly who was resposible for the success of It Happened One Night when, after accepting her award, she graciously told the Academy. "I owe Frank Capra for this."  So do we.My rating: 3 and a half stars

Three time Oscar winning director Frank Capra emerged as one of the most successful filmmakers before, during, and after World War II with classics such as "Mr. Deeds Goes to Town" (1936), "Lost Horizon" (1937), "You Can't Take It With You" (1938), "Mr. Smith Goes to Washington" (1939), "Meet John Doe" (1941), "Arsenic and Old Lace" (1944), "It's a Wonderful Life" (1946) and "State of the Union" (1948). Before he made movie history with these films, he helmed the first Hollywood epic to receive all five top Oscars, including Best Picture, Best Director, Best Actor, Best Actress, and Best Screenwriter. Starring Clark Gable and Claudette Colbert, "It Happened One Night" qualifies as a road trip comedy about a millionaire banker's daughter on the lam from her dominating father and a newspaperman abetting heiress' every move until they break up inevitable and then reunite at fade-out. Louis B. Mayor loaned out Clark Gable to Columbia Pictures as punishment for refusing to make a movie. Mayer's strategy, however, backfired. You see, the Academy awarded Gable the Oscar for Best Actor. Claudette Colbert received the Oscar for Best Actress, too! Culturally, this contagiously funny comedy of errors is memorable for two scenes. First, Gable shed his shirt and displayed his bare chest. Undershirt sales as a result plummeted. Actually, according to IMDb.COM, Gable ditched his undershirt because it interfered with the flow of the scene when he was shedding his apparel. Second, Colbert flaunted her leg when Gable cannot thumb them a ride. Indeed, history takes some interesting turns. Reportedly, Colbert lambasted the movie before it became a big hit. Furthermore, she dictated that Capra had to lense the action in four weeks. According to Frank Capra, Jr., Columbus paid Colbert twice her salary. "It Happened One Night" brought Columbia Pictures its first Best Picture Oscar.Millionaire banker Andrews takes his own daughter Ellie (Claudette Colbert) hostage on his own yacht after she marries the thrill seeking aviator King Westley. Actually, Andrews detests Westley and later pays him off with $100-thousand dollars. Ellie refuses to let her father coop her up against her will so she dives off the yacht and swims ashore. Andrews offers a ten-thousand dollar reward for her whereabouts. Ellie decides to maintain a low profile by traveling by bus. During the bus trip, she encounters an out-of-work newspaperman, Peter Warne (Clark Gable) and they begin their relationship as adversaries until things change. The wealthy heiress loses her suitcase when a thief snatches it right from under her nose while she is leaning against the bus smoking a cigarette. Warne decides to play Sir Galahad and helps her out when he discovers that Ellie is the object of a national manhunt. Ellie misses the bus after a scheduled stop because she mistakenly believes that the bus company will wait on her. Warne sticks around the bus depot, hands Ellie her ticket, and helps her board another bus. Back aboard the bus, Ellie encounters a character named Oscar Shapeley (Roscoe Karns), and Peter saves her from an evening of his company. A washed-out bridge halts the Atlantic Greyhound Bus. Conserving their dwindling funds, Peter checks them into a cabin as a married couple. In this hilarious scene, Peter strings a blanket that he designates 'the Walls of Jericho' across the room between them as they sleep in separate beds. Our hero conspires to help Ellie hook up with King Westley on the grounds that she gives him the scoop on her saga. During a convivial moment when everybody is singing the song about the man on the flying trapeze, the bus driver steers the vehicle into a hole, and Shapeley makes his big move. Shapeley has learned about the reward so he tries to get Peter to share it with him. Cleverly, Peter lies to Shapeley tells him that he is a gangster who has abducted Ellie. In no time, Shapeley makes himself scarce. Afraid that Shapeley (Roscoe Karns)will still try to get word to Andrews about Ellie, Peter convinces her that they need to refrain from using the bus as transportation. Peter has no luck at hitchhiking until Ellie displays her legs and a motorist (Allen Hale) pulls over and gives them a ride. Naturally, Peter is upset that Ellie has saved the day for them. They get into an argument and things go from bad to worse. Meantime, Ellie's father experiences a change of heart and seek to win Ellie back even if it means accepting Wesley. "It Happened One Night" wraps up with a happy ending.This is a Hollywood classic worth seeing a dozen times or more. Colbert is the original runaway bride.

Societies undergo phase changes...like the change from water into ice.The year 1934 was perhaps the middle of one such phase change in the US: national Prohibition was gone, it was around the depth of the Depression and the paternalistic Hays Code was on its way in with full force. Silent films were dead, 'talkies' were here to stay -- it allowed us the chance to laugh and sing along with the actors in the film. What could have been better in such dismal times?Looking at it that way, one can see why "It Happened..." was showered with adoration. But it just doesn't resonate today...there have been additional phase changes in the interim.In terms of content, this is watchable only for Gable's performance, who towers over everyone else here. Simultaneously, he smirks for the audience in recognition of his own power. The plot pinballs off of the newspaper headlines, which keeps the mood light.However, in form, this offers nothing as a *cinematic* experience. There's no change of perspective from our day to day world...it could all be played out on a stage. Heck, you could turn your back to the viewing screen and follow what's going on from the audio content -- like a period radio show.It's for this astounding lack of cinematic qualities that I must rank it so low. If you want a far superior and more effective example of visual storytelling, go with Hitchcock's "The 39 Steps".

... holds up across generations. I saw this movie for the first time in over two decades New Years Eve. I had intended to watch only the first few minutes before flipping channels, but was swept into the farcical situation and ended up going to my New Years party somewhat later than intended. Claudette Colbert and Clark Gable were inimitably charming and delightful... their clothed banter had more scorching sexual innuendo than most of today's stars can muster. I'm no prude, some of my favorite flicks my grandparents would probably have a heart attack if they were alive to view, but it was curiously refreshing to enjoy a "wholesome" sexual comedy. Capra's film is truly a movie for the ages.

reviews.review_title: Colbert Can Catch a Lift with Me Any Day
reviews.content: "It Happened One Night" is an example of what happens when everything in a movie works just right. This movie probably had low aspirations when it was first released in 1934, but everything clicked so well that it's now considered to be the supreme example of screwball comedy, one of the best movies of the 30s, and one of the best movies of all time.Clark Gable and the adorable Claudette Colbert could not have more chemistry together. Their sassy back and forth is a joy to watch. And though this movie came out in the first year of the enforced Production Code, their relationship is refreshingly sexy. Dig Clark Gable in his undershirt (gasp!). And check out Claudette Colbert's shapely gams when she uses them to hitch a ride in one of the movie's classic scenes.Though the film is light and frothy, the spectre of the Depression isn't totally absent. For example, in one brief scene, Gable pauses at a railroad crossing to watch a freight train go past, loaded with hobos presumably off to find work somewhere, anywhere they can. One wonders if this was even staged or if Capra happened to catch an authentic moment from a dark time in America's history.The screwball comedy is not a genre that's managed to survive throughout the years, so all the more reason to enjoy this funny, breezy, sophisticated piece of cinema magic.Grade: A+

reviews.review_title: This Film Should Happen Several Nights.
reviews.content: It Happened One Night (1934): Dir: Frank Capra / Cast: Clark Gable, Claudette Colbert, Walter Connolly, Roscoe Karns, Alan Hale: Charming romantic road comedy about chance encounters. It stars Claudette Colbert as heiress Ellen Andrews who is eloping with a man whom her wealthy father objects too. He demands an annulment but she runs away boarding a bus to New York. On the bus she encounters a drunken struggling newspaper journalist Peter Warne, played by Clark Gable. He promises to help her get to New York if she grant him her publicized annulment details while on the road. Reluctantly, she agree and as predicted they go from bickering couple to actually falling in love. What works is a climax that bares charm and integrity. This becomes one of Frank Capra's biggest directional efforts and it works largely thanks to the chemistry between the leads. Gable brings much humour due to quirky dialogue and a knack for winning the argument, but he plays Warne with heart. Colbert plays the spoiled heiress set in her rebellious ways until a man like Warne says, "no." Walter Connolly plays her strict father who comes around for the right suitor. Roscoe Karns steals moments harassing Colbert on the bus. Alan Hale has a comical appearance as someone who picks them up hitchhiking and then attempts to steal their belongings but is stopped by Gable. Theme switches actions, attitudes, and mental destinations. Score: 9 / 10

But it was Claudette Colbert who knew exactly who was responsible for It Happened One Night when, after accepting her award, she graciously told the Academy, "I owe Frank Capra for this."  She did and so do we.My rating: 3 stars

reviews.review_title: One of the best romantic comedies of all time
reviews.content: This is one of the best comedy-romance films ever made. It isn't the funniest movie, by a long shot. It doesn't' have the running dialog of witty repartee. There's no slapstick and there are no pratfalls. No scenes lead to rollicking laughter. There are no hilarious escapades or frantic goings on as in screwball comedies. There are no zany scenes of frantic farce as in the best Marx Brothers films. And, the film doesn't spoof or poke fun at various groups. Perhaps the absence of so much in these areas is what befuddled some of Hollywood and the critics - but not all. Because even the members of the film academy saw something special in "It Happened One Night."They may have been swayed by public opinion, when this low-budget, second-tier studio movie packed the theaters and topped the all-time box office for Columbia studios to that time. It finished the year in fourth place, after such lavish MGM productions as "Viva Villa" and "The Barretts of Wimpole Street," and the Paramount extravaganza, "Cleopatra." There's more than a little irony in the fact that Claudette Colbert won the best actress Oscar for this film, and wasn't nominated for her role in "Cleopatra." Especially, when most film histories note that Colbert told associates that she had just finished making the worst film ever, when shooting finished on "One Night."Not only did the public like this film, but the academy honored it with the big five Academy Awards. Columbia was then a second tier studio, but won for best picture. Clark Gable and Colbert won the top acting awards. Frank Capra won for directing, and Robert Riskin won for the screenplay. "It Happened One Night" was the first film to win the big five Oscars, and the only one to do so for more than four decades. Only two others have done that since - "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" in 1975, and "The Silence of the Lambs" in 1991.My DVD of the film has a special feature short, "Frank Capra, Jr. remembers 'It Happened One Night.'" It was made for Columbia Tri-Star in 1999 and has interviews with Frank Capra, Jr. He had an erudite observation of how performers can misread the quality of a movie. It explains how Colbert thought so lowly of this film until after her Oscar. "Many times," Capra Jr. says, "actors don't realize what is being made. They see today's dailies, they see tomorrow's, they see yesterday's. It's disjointed. They don't know which takes are being picked. They don't know how it's being edited. They don't know what's in the director's mind of how this picture is going to actually be. So, sometimes they don't realize what their part is like."So, what is it about this film that makes it so great? It's a very good plot - and one of the first that began a decade-long run of rich heiress films. The comedy was subdued in places, and the film had a perfect mix of romance and humor within a range of different encounters and events. It was a perfect setting for a road-trip romance. And this film came out early in 1934, just when Hollywood was beginning to enforce its production code (aka the Hays Office, Breen Code, etc.). The only "daring" scenes that came anywhere near raising censorship eyebrows were Clark Gable taking off his shirt to show his bare chest, and Colbert's lifting of her dress to above her knee as a hitchhiking ploy to stop the next car. This one in particular is worth a hearty laugh because of the expression on Gable's face when she does that. It's a perfect representation of the culture of the time. The film is a prime example of the better humor that often came out of Hollywood films that toned down the "risqué chart" in favor of clean, genuine comedy."It Happened One Night" will likely remain a favorite for generations to come. It's a movie that leaves one satisfied and smiling. One has a feeling of having spent a couple of entertainment hours very well.Here are a couple of favorite lines.Ellie Andrews (Claudette Colbert), "Aren't you going to give me a little credit?" Peter Warne (Clark Gable), "What for?" Andrews, "Well, I proved once and for all that the limb is mightier than the thumb."Peter Warne, "Why didn't you take off all your clothes? You could've stopped 40 cars." Andrews, "Oh, I'll remember that - when we need 40 cars."

The ONLY good thing about this movie is Clark Gable whose shirtless scenes actually led to a decrease in undershirt sales in the United States upon this movies release (that's true, and the funniest thing about this movie). Now I'm not someone who is opposed to old movies or even old comedies (though I think that pretty much all of them are products of their times, as are movies today).  But I don't find this movie funny at all.  It doesn't have witty lines and verbal humor nor does it have much slapstick or goofy stuff.  It doesn't really have any funny material, unless you find some annoying sailors on a bus singing the "daring young man on the trapeze" to be hilarious.  BTW the one sailors solo and dance proves that gays have been in the military for at least 70 years.  Even the Romantic portion of this movie is weak, mainly considering that Claudette's character is very unappealing.  She is really winey and not funny at all.  If you are looking for a classic comedy check out The Marx Brothers, The Thin Man series (which I think are still hilarious today, Asta alone is better then this entire movie), W.C. Fields, or even Buster Keaton (if you want to go that far back...he is better then Chaplin).  I guess I'd recommend this movie to Gable fans or people who want to see what won best picture in 1934 (im sure there was something better).  This is just one of those movies that has since attained untouchable classic status and is on the critics funniest movie lists.  It isn't funny and as much as I hate to admit it, I laughed more watching Happpy Gilmore (I don't like Sandler) then I did at this movie.
Zoopansick

I am a huge classic movie fan, but I haven't invested much time in pre-1940s movies. Almost 100% indoor sets & poor picture quality somehow discouraged me to be perfectly honest, however lame that sounds. "It Happened One Night" was encouraging thanks to Frank Capra & Clark Gable. I haven't seen too many of Gable's movies except Gone with the Wind. However, I did not know what to expect from him in such a jolly, maverick role. He was absolutely brilliant. His deliveries were so sharp, his sense of humour was so good, I had no doubt since then why he was such a popular man among the ladies. His intro scene is absolutely hilarious and reveals much of what to expect from him. You couldn't blame Claudette Colbert for falling in love with him; even for 30s, he wasn't a boring "gentleman", but a cool guy. He had his own reasons, sense of morality and more importantly, real and like much of America then, poor. Its absolutely enjoyable ride, no matter which type of movies you enjoy. I'd give it an 8+ happily!

I have seen a few Frank Capra movies in my day, and I must say that this is my favorite of his films. Every modern romantic comedy, from "The Graduate" to "When Harry Met Sally" to "Sleepless in Seattle", owes a serious debt to the film that all but spawned the genre, "It Happened One Night".It can be argued that film was lucky to even get off the ground. This film was produced at several different locations on a shoestring budget (with Claudette Colbert receiving a large chunk of that budget as pay), yet the chemistry between Colbert and Clark Gable was among the best ever caught on film. Also, Capra's efficient directing style, which became a necessity for this project, paid off in spades."It Happened One Night" caused a sensation from the word "go". T-shirt sales dropped because Clark Gable didn't wear one in the film. The phrase "Walls of Jericho" became a part of the American lexicon. It showed that women could indeed get just about anything they wanted, just by showing a little leg. And it has been acknowledged in several circles that "It Happened One Night" was the inspiration behind the creation of one of most-loved cartoon characters ever, Bugs Bunny.It would be hard to pick just one reason to watch this film, but if I had to choose, it would be the scene in which Peter (Gable) and Ellie (Colbert) pretend to be a married blue-collar couple when private detectives hired by Ellie's father encounter them at a motor lodge. This scene alone demonstrates Gable's and Colbert's chemistry with each other (I know I've mentioned it before. Trust me -- It's that good!).The first film to win Oscars for Best Picture, Director, Actor, Actress, and Screenplay, "It Happened One Night" is a heartwarming, charming, hilarious movie that I would recommend for any couple (young or old) to see. This is the first truly great romantic comedy, which still holds up pretty well (Okay, so taking the bus isn't very romantic anymore).By the way, I showed selected scenes of this film to my son when he was 16, and he liked what he saw. If that isn't a ringing endorsement, I don't know what is!

Based on all the historical accolades, I decided to watch this "classic". After enduring to the bitter end, the most flattering thing I can say is that the camera appeared to be in focus for the full duration of the film. I'm willing to make concessions given the cultural differences of the time periods, but I can't imagine that peoples innate senses of humor and romance have changed THAT much. I mean really, did folks back in the day think dissertations on dunking donuts and piggy-back rides were funny? I realize the players in older films can be exaggerated and caricatures, but the obnoxious male bus passenger was just too much. It was one of many cringe-worthy scenes that left me wondering if the art of writing screen plays was in it's infancy. Incidentally, who didn't think Peter's terrorist threats against the bus guy's family were a howler! I'm still laughing at that one?!?!As for chemistry between the two stars, distilled water appears more reactive. Peter was a self-righteous grouch who wanted some dream "dame" who likes to frolic on the beach and look at the stars. Who wouldn't want a guy like that? She..., come to think of it, I don't remember anything about her desires or ambitions. Her facial expressions and lack of anything resembling passion were confusing. There was nothing to like on either side. He wasn't an appealing character and she was boring.I will say the movie was funny as an audience participation event. When Peter ran and caught a car to retrieve his belongings from a film-flam man, I couldn't help busting a gut. Either the cars were very slow in those days, or the cigarettes they were smoking really did make them more fit. Either way, there were several "incredible" circumstances in the movie that had me chuckling.I suppose the movie wasn't a complete waste of time, but I'm still wondering what happened and on which night?

Ellie Andrews, an heiress, has married a dashing pilot named King Westley against the wishes of millionaire father, Alexander. He tries to keep Ellie a prisoner on his yacht until she agrees to have the marriage annulled, but she runs away and boards a bus bound for New York, where she hopes to be reunited with her husband. Now at this stage the audience doubtless think they know how the movie will end. Westley will be the hero, the villainous Alexander will get his come-uppance and true love will ultimately triumph. Only it doesn't quite work out like that. True love does indeed win the day, but not between Ellie and Westley, who proves to be an unscrupulous fortune-hunter. Ellie's true love turns out to be Peter Warne, an unemployed journalist whom she meets on the bus. At first Peter's only interest in Ellie is also financial; her elopement has aroused great media interest and he believes that if he can get an exclusive on her story, he will be able to get his old job back. After a number of adventures, however, they start to fall in love."It Happened One Night" was one of the last American films made before the production code came into force in 1934, and might have had difficulties getting past the Hays Office had it been made a few months later. That does not mean, however, that there is anything particularly permissive about it by modern standards. There is no violence, and no sex scenes, unless the sequence in which Claudette Colbert stops a car by showing a shapely leg counts as a scene of a sexual nature. Its rather cavalier attitude to marriage, however, might have struck some as excessively daring by the standards of the thirties. Certainly, there were plenty of screwball romantic comedies ("The Women", "My Favourite Wife", "His Girl Friday", "The Philadelphia Story") involving divorce during the late thirties and early forties, but most of these ended up with divorced or separated couples getting back together, which made them more acceptable to the censors. "It Happened One Night" is a romantic comedy which actually involves a couple who start off married and end up with their marriage annulled.This was the first film to win all "Big Five" Academy Awards, namely Best Picture, Best Director (Frank Capra), Best Actor (Clark Gable), Best Actress (Colbert) and Best Screenplay (Robert Riskin). This feat would not be equalled for over forty years; it was eventually to be matched by "One Flew over the Cuckoo's Nest" in 1975 and later by "The Silence of the Lambs" in 1991. In the case of "It Happened One Night" it must be said that all five awards were well-deserved. As was often the case with screwball comedies the basic plot is pretty implausible, but Riskin's script is so sharp, witty and fast-moving that we hardly notice.Gable and Colbert combine so well that it is strange to think that neither was the first choice of the producers. Robert Montgomery rejected the part of Peter and Colbert was only cast as Ellie after several other actresses had turned it down and Warner Brothers had refused to lend Bette Davis, who wanted the role, to Columbia. Colbert herself, in fact, was initially reluctant to take the part, allegedly because she had clashed with Capra while making another film with him some years earlier, but was persuaded to accept by an increase in her salary.Capra today has the reputation of being a director of sentimental comedies which helped Americans to feel better during the tough years of the Great Depression and World War II. There is an element of this in "It Happened One Night" with its Cinderella-in-reverse "rich girl marries poor boy" plot, but there is more to the film than that. It is a film where our expectations are constantly reversed. Ellie, the spoilt, pampered socialite, turns out to be much more resourceful than we might have imagined. Westley, who we expect will turn out to be the hero, turns out to be the nearest thing the film has to a villain, although as he benefits financially from his short-lived marriage there is a happy ending even for him. Peter, the cynical, down-on-his-luck reporter, proves to have hidden reserves of decency. Even Alexander is not such a bully as he at first appears. (And he was dead right about Westley's unsuitability as a husband for his daughter). Capra and Riskin are essentially playing games with and subverting standard movie clichés, producing a modern fairy-tale for the twentieth century. They succeeded so well that the film remains fresh fifteen years into the twenty-first, more than eighty years after it was made. The makers of modern rom-coms, with a few honourable exceptions a pretty fossilised genre today, could learn a lot from them. 8/10

The classic story of Night Bus hits the screen in the greatest comedy romance adventure of all time. Oscar winner for Actor and Actress (Gable and Cobert) Director,Screenplay and best yet, PICTURE. Entertaining all the way,hillariously funny, and a gripping romance adventure mark it as one of the best films ever made.Don't even ask the plot, SEE IT!!!!!!!!

'It Happened One Night (1934)' is the blueprint for almost every romantic comedy that came after it, actually being somewhat surprising in terms of how closely it conforms to the tropes that still adorn its genre to this very day. Of course, the reality is that the piece is creating a genre, not conforming to one. This inherently reduces the picture's potential 'seen it before' factor; we may have, but audiences at the time certainly hadn't. It sort of highlights just how formulaic even the very best rom-coms tend to be, primarily because they all feature at least one element that this flick first established. Seriously, it's all here: the will they/ won't they dynamic, the contrasting personalities, the bickering, the banter, the humour, the heart, the misunderstandings, the domineering parent, the other man, the 'all is lost' mix-up, the wedding-based finale... the list goes on. That's not to say it feels especially derivative, though - I mean, how could it? It holds up remarkably well considering its age, primarily because its lead actors - despite both apparently having no love for the movie - share a palpable chemistry and do the quick-witted dialogue justice. It's constantly moving towards its compellingly frustrating finale, barely wasting a second. In many ways, it's remarkably ahead of its time. In some others, of course, it isn't. For instance, Gable's leading man starts out as a bit of a creep and then becomes a straight-up jerk for the majority of the movie (he even threatens to break Colbert's character's neck at one point). Still, it's obviously a product of its time. In the end, it's an enjoyable and hugely influential romantic comedy. 7/10

a strange movie. for the special mixture between romantic comedy, historical importance, inspired performance and the science to be ever green. a film who seduce and impress for the status of beginner in a common but not easy domain. because it gives image of few stereotypes but, in same measure, it is a perfect model for acting in best manner in this genre. Clark Gable does a very interesting role and Claudette Colbert is really brilliant but my favorite remains Walter Connolly for his splendid art to translate the emotions of a father, force of rich man and wise character in Shakespeare jester form. a beautiful film who is little more than slice from old period or a comedy from others but a nice example of impeccable work.

I've lately been watching a number of films made in the early 30's and it just strikes me watching "It Happened One Night" how unlike all the others it was, good as they sometimes were. I know it was the first screwball comedy, something in itself, but it's Capra's moving camera, the snappy dialogue and the credible acting even in unlikely situations that make you feel less like you're watching something staged. In all those senses, it plays like the first modern movie. Crazy as they sometimes are, Gable and Colbert's characters feel like real people, talking and acting naturally as they go. It's also a film made for adults to enjoy, the for-the-times risqué humour concerning the erection (no pun intended) of the symbolic Walls of Jericho between the thrown together couple, Gable's undressing to his bare torso, Colbert's hitching a ride for them by provocatively hitching her skirt and the closing consummation scene where the walls come tumbling down are all knowingly and winningly rendered.Gable is great in the role that elevated him to his unchallenged status as the King Of Hollywood, the personification of contemporary masculinity, handsome, confident and honourable and yet not without sensitivity or good manners. Colbert is equally good as the spoiled brat who is brought down to earth on the road with Gable. She's sexy, sassy and chic and every bit the match of Gable, a prototype for the smart-talking female characters to be played in succeeding Hollywood comedies starring the likes of Rosalind Russell, Katharine Hepburn, Jean Arthur, Barbra Stanwyck, Carole Lombard and others. The starring couple's interaction and comic timing is perfect, a model for all those initially-warring-couple features for years to come.With a witty script by Robert Ruskin, an able supporting cast and a succession of humorous situations, the film flows beautifully from the off, never letting up, directed energetically and at times almost instinctively by Capra in the movie that really made his name. There are no lingering close-ups, static scene-setting or slow dissolves here, it's all pace and movement as befits the plight of the runaway couple.Capra's social commentary is still evident and doesn't gloss over its Depression Era setting, manifest in the scene when Gable salutes the everyday folk riding the top of the train which crosses his path. Capra didn't really return to screwball comedy after making this, instead going on in later years to further exercise his conscience by employing Messrs Deeds, Smith and Doe, but he didn't need to, he nailed it forever with this marvellous one-off collective collaboration, almost unbelievably shot in only four weeks.

You can't go wrong with this one. I love the fact that on their escapade through many types of transportation you get to see a lot of what America was back in the 30's. How people were, society etc. Obviously this is a movie and not a documentary but a glimpse into it. Great acting between the leads abounds or this would have been pretty dry. It's fun, it's comfortable and we all know where it's going. But it's a nice ride to get there.I give it 9/10 carrots.

One of the most important Best Picture winners feels like one of the most unnecessary Best Picture winners by some. When one says "Best Picture Winner", you think the said film must meet a certain criteria, such as war drama or epic production value-centric story, that certifies it that prestigious title. It Happened One Night has neither of those, though it does achieve a wonderful romance brought to life by Clarke Gable and Claudette Colbert and contains a screenplay as fresh as the carrots Clarke Gable eats himself during the picture.Movies of the 1930s (and earlier) have reoccurring problems when they are put up to the task of competing with newer pictures using today's standards of film perfection: they lack the tight, technical exertion. The sound is often terrible, some dialogue may even be lost, the editing is probably loose, and the photography is assumably rugged from the restoration attempts by the studios. It Happened One Night falls prey to these shortcomings, but it's the film's only real flaw, and not a big one at that. It's still a fairly entertaining movie and the restoration is actually successful most of the times.I couldn't take my eyes of It Happened One Night! It's a delightful film that should not be missed by any generation. Before Pretty Woman and Annie Hall were "the" romantic comedies of their times, there was It Happened One Night. Most of the romantic comedy plot devices we've seen used repeatedly, originated here and were so accepted by audiences and writers that they have grown into cliché. Aside from that, It Happened One Night combines classic stories (poor little rich girl, desperate reporter, train rides, extramarital affairs) into one sublime, Hollywood picture. The thing to any successful romantic comedy, besides the script having more on its cutting board than what the average joe-blow can bring to the table, is its stars. Think about how successful those two rom-coms I mentioned earlier would have been without Julia Roberts and Richard Gere or Woody Allen and Diane Keaton? Not very. The leading couple not only has marvelous chemistry together, but they both have the bolts to screw in a great performances. Clarke Gable in particular shines. His movie-star presence and ability to flow with a picture and character are on full display here. Claudette Colbert produces first rate acting, as well.It Happened One Night is a greatly pleasing film. You'll watch it with a smile on your face. It's funny and contains one of the best movie romances out there, a relationship that starts out in hostility, evolves to friendship, and is overcome with the realization of love. It Happened One Night is cute and having inspired a whole genre of films ahead of its time.Rating: 10/10Grade: A+

I enter every movie viewing with energy and delight, and this time was no different, but by the time that thing was over I was angry. I am shocked that this is a classic and won so many awards- shocked, to an extent. I'm aware that society was ~different~ back then but I can't just ignore the blatant sexism prevalent in films from this time. In the same way that a racist movie would infuriate me beyond my ability to ignore for entertainment's sake, the disgusting misogyny in this film made it nearly unbearable. People say, "it was a different time!" but I don't care. It's disgusting now, it was disgusting back then, and no art/entertainment gets a pardon just because it was a hit when it came out.Despite this film having a female lead, she was nothing but a plot device. How the main character could make a total of ONE decision of her own within the span of an entire feature film is truly beyond me. Summaries of the film cushion the plot with things like, "she agrees to help him if he keeps her secret" but in actuality this was a woman on the run from a controlling father who was threatened with violence into giving that sleazy reporter a story or else he would give her up to that controlling father. Literally romanticized Stockholm's Syndrome. This is described as a romance movie but there was nothing romantic about it. This is a movie about men wanting a woman to do what they want instead of what she wants. The word "demented" popped into my mind multiple times while watching in reaction to things these men would do to her.The characters were really annoying, all of them. The things that were supposed to be romantic were just gross. There must be a million ways to make a story about a runaway heiress, you know? It's an interesting premise but it was executed incredibly poorly, with totally unlikeable characters and multiple disturbing dynamics in play. Plot holes so enormous even the male lead's gigantic head would get lost in them. Professional appearance, decent sound, standard cinematography- not a particularly artistic film. Weak story, poorly told, no character development besides developing them from strangers to creepy, controlling jerks. I hope no bizarre situation occurs in which I am ever forced to watch this again.4/10 Bye love you

reviews.review_title: Even After 80 Years, It Happened One Night Lives Up To Its Legacy
reviews.content: Winner of 5 Academy Awards including Best Picture, and the very first film to win the Oscar "Grand Slam"; a feat only two other films have been able to accomplish so far, It Happened One Night is a wonderfully balanced, oddly whimsical & neatly executed romantic comedy that still retains & resonates all its charm despite being over 80 years old.It Happened One Night tells the story of a spoiled socialite who runs away from her father's clutches to get back to her lover, whom her father disapproves of. While on the bus to New York City, she meets an out-of-work reporter who's in search of an interesting story, and on recognising her in the papers, makes a deal to help her reach New York in exchange for an exclusive on her story.Directed by Frank Capra, the film is sprinkled with fine dose of humour, romance & drama from start to finish, keeps its light-hearted tone alive throughout its 105 minutes of runtime & never loses its momentum at any given moment. Coming to the performances, both Clark Gable & Claudette Colbert chip in with commendable work while their on-screen chemistry is even more impressive.On an overall scale, It Happened One Night is an expertly directed, deftly written & superbly performed cinema that brims with heart, humour & entertainment, and remains as effective today as it was back in its time of release. Cited by many as the first true screwball comedy though I have no idea what it even means, It Happened One Night is a highly enjoyable ride that comes thoroughly recommended.

The 1934 American film, "It happened one night" directed by Frank Capra, is a perfect example of a screw-ball comedy. Starring such actors as Clark Gable, Claudette Colbert, and Walter Conelly, this was the first film to ever win all five major Academy Awards(Best Picture, Director, Actor, Actress, and Screenplay). I personally thought that this film was quiet comical and thoroughly enjoyed the story. I also thought that it was filmed perfectly, which a great example of this being the bus scene. One thing that I thought was interesting, was the fact that during this era, movies weren't really able to depict relationships and romance, but they found ways to get around it. All in all I give, "It happened one night" 5.5 out of 6 chicken nuggets.

Newspaper reporter Peter Warne (Clark Gable) is rather full of himself. He thinks he is the best reporter. He fancies himself an expert on every subject, from donut dunking to piggybacking to hitchhiking techniques. While riding a bus, he stumbles into the biggest story of the year: an heiress, against the wishes of her father, has run away to be with her boyfriend. Ellie (Claudette Colbert) is determined to defy her father if only because she likes defiance.Director Frank Capra created a classic with this film. It feels like he and Gable added so much to the script in the shooting---plenty of funny flourishes that elevate this romantic comedy. The Oscar haul says it all: Best Writing, Best Picture, Best Director, Best Actor, Best Actress.If you watch closely, you can see the moments when the relationship between Peter and Ellie transitions from contentious to cooperative to caring. It takes real talent to make these moments so believable.This is one film I enjoy rewatching periodically. It never loses its appeal. And it is my favorite Capra film.

reviews.review_title: "I want to see what love looks like . . . "
reviews.content: " . . . when it's triumphant." So says Clark Gable, as jaded alcoholic big city reporter Peter Warne. The girl of his dreams appears to be swirling down the drain. It's been a tough week. He loses his job. He pawns nearly everything he owns. He sleeps under a haystack. He gets robbed. He steals cars and carrots himself. But the millionaire is "reimbursing" him $39.60. That's a start. In 1934, forty bucks can buy a lot more booze than it would today. And unlike the preceding 15 years, it is even legal to swill it. Yet, in a few moments, the worm may turn once more. The self-declared married-but-virgin heiress he's been shacked up with these past seven days has one last chance to come to her senses. Could there be a fifth verse of "The Daring Young Man on the Flying Trapeze" sung? Can a plumber's daughter eat raw vegetables? Will the "Walls of Jericho" finally tumble? Toot toot!

Tracy and Hepburn, Hanks and Ryan; none of these romantic pairings can match Lombard and Gable. Back in the thirties they set the bar, and no one has surpassed it. And few movies can match It Happened One Night. It has not aged a bit and is still as fresh and witty and loveable as it was in 1934. Anyone who has not see this movie, should. Seek it out.

I finally saw this movie tonight! The only things that I knew about it were the famous Gable "no undershirt" scene and the famous Colbert "hitchhiking" scene. It didn't disappoint. It was like an archaeological look back in time to the original "ROM-COM" master movie, and it still holds up after all these years. Think about it...it was made over 3/4 of a century ago. To put it in another perspective, if you went back an additional 76 years from when this was made, it would be Pre-Civil War! It's important to remember that this was made in the height of the Great Depression, and note the strict moral code of the time, fully incorporated into the movie. However the total sexual tension was fully exploited in the movie, and still applies today. I also appreciated the technique in the final scene, of letting the audience imagine what's happening, when the "walls of Jerico" finally go tumbling down!Capra's directing and choice of shots and perspectives was amazing too! It really set the standard for all these genre of movies that have since followed. Very watchable, Very entertaining. One final thought....as I watched Gable in this movie, his facial expressions and mannerisms totally made me think of Johnny Depp, who I now realize is the modern day Gable! Watch this movie and don't think too much...just let yourself be entertained.

"It Happened One Night" is a comedy movie which is being very well combined with romance and it shows us a spoiled heiress who is running away from her father. In her try one man who is also a reporter is helping her in order to have a story to sell to his boss.I liked this movie because of the nice plot but most of all because of the cast and their interpretations. Especially I liked very much the interpretation of Clark Gable who played as Peter Warne and I believe that he was simply outstanding in his role. I also want to mention that this movie is a really enjoyable movie because it has a good plot which is combined very well with the interpretations of the cast and of course the direction which is made by Frank Capra.Finally I believe that "It Happened One Night" is a very good movie to watch and I strongly recommend it. This movie wants to show us how things change in life when some events happen and we have to be prepared for everything from the worst to the best.

reviews.review_title: It Happened One Night- A League of its Own
reviews.content: This film richly deserved Best Film of 1934 and all the other awards it garnered. In making the male lead both a hero and comedian, Frank Capra copies the formula created by Charlie Chaplin, Harold Lloyd, Buster Keaton and a few others in silent film.Capra, however, is able to add verbal dialogue to the comedian/hero formula, thereby taking the formula into the talkie era. Several of his films feature this successful combination. Enjoy this one for the first, or even the second time. Great films are made to be seen more than once.

It Happened One Night is renowned, the extent of which I was not aware till my husband and I were watching 'Bandits' (with Billy Bob Thornton, Bruce Willis, and Cate Blanchett). Bruce Willis puts the blanket up on a string between them on the bed and Cate Blanchett says, "Oh, like from that old movie!" I automatically said, "It Happened One Night." "What?" Says my hubby. "The movie, 'It Happened One Night'." "That's in a lot of movies, babe." Says he. "Yes, but it's the original. Clark Gable strung it up and called it the walls of Jericho, and in the end, when that wedding that Bruce (in Bandits) is referring to taking place at the end is his and Claudette Colbert's, and then they 'bring down the wall'." I now am on a mission to add this to my NetFlix list so I might better edify my hubby on the subject. A definite must-see or, if possible, must-own for any movie buff. Witty, at times slap-stick, and charming in a way movies today simply are not. And for the ladies, a chance to see a handsome 33 year old Gable.
