*Emotion- A watchable and classic film about the battle between sexes, rich & poor, and North & South with a happy ending.*Based On- Best selling novel.

reviews.review_title: First Screwball Comedy and First to Win the 'Big Five' Academy Awards
reviews.content: It's rare the Academy Awards hands out the 'Big Five' Oscars to one motion picture: Best Picture, Best Director, Best Actor, Best Actress and Best Adapted Screenplay. In fact, only two other films hold that honor after February 1934's "It Happened One Night" achieved the seemingly impossible. Strangely, the Columbia Pictures' movie was initially a production no one wanted to be involved. Several top-flight stars rejected having anything to do with the production after reading the script, including Miriam Hopkins, Myrna Loy, Margaret Sullavan, Frederic March and Robert Montgomery, who later called it the worst screenplay he had ever read. Columbia boss Harry Cohn recommended actress Claudette Colbert to director Frank Capra to play the role of 'Ellie' Andres, who escapes from her wealthy father by diving off his Florida yacht to return to New York to re-unite with her recently married husband. Her father loathes the man and demands the marriage be annulled. Colbert had bad memories dealing with Capra in the first movie she ever appeared in, 1927's silent 'For the Love of Mike," and vowed never to work for him again. To discourage the hiring, she demanded double her salary of $50,000. Surprisingly, Columbia met her request.Capra, after hearing so many actors reject the screenplay, asked his writer friend Myles Connolly what he thought of the script. His advice: make Ellie more sympathetic. Screenwriter Robert Riskin reworked the script based on Samuel Hopkins Adams' 1933 short story 'Night Bus' to do just that. Still, the rewrite didn't improve Colbert's disposition on the set. She bickered with Capra throughout the four weeks of filming. She told her friends "I just finished the worst picture in the world."Clark Gable was equally unenthusiastic about the project. MGM loaned out the actor since his next studio film wasn't ready for some weeks, and his $2,000 a-week salary would be paid by Columbia. His first words to Capra on the initial day of shooting was "Let's get this over with."Once "It Happened One Night" was released to major city theaters, critics were lukewarm towards the film. The New Yorker review scathingly wrote "pretty much nonsense and quite dreary." The initial short run at the large city movie houses was drawing only a mediocre audience. The film then played at smaller venues and towns. Suddenly, through word of mouth, lines formed out the door anxious to see Gable, as Peter Warne, a jaded know-it-all newspaper reporter just fired from his job who meets up with Ellie on the bus journeying north from Florida. The movie struck a special cord to rural Americans who were experiencing a lack of jobs, food, and shelter during the Depression. Roger Ebert noted in his review of "It Happened One Night, "The communal singing of "The Man on the Flying Trapeze" interrupts the action and morphs into a wonderfully democratic vision of the night bus as a society in eternal transit."That bus ride scene was particularly instructive in how Capra, through his years of living in poverty, instinctively reframed it in the middle of filming. The director at first hired a small band to play "The Man on the Flying Trapeze" to a bus full of lower class travelers, including the two leads. Amazingly, all the extras knew the entire words to the song and sang it on the set. "Another idea." recalls Capra. "Why not let the whole bus join in? And that's what finally evolved." He praised small Columbia for allowing such independence that larger studios would have a committee of executives deciding on the director's preference."It Happened One Night" is filled with such classic scenes. When a bridge washed out the road during a rainstorm delaying the bus, Ellie and Peter are forced to share a motel room. The script called for Gable to strip down to his undies, describing each phase of his undressing. Gable's slick-tongue narrative got hung up when he had to remove his undershirt. Capra decided to bag the T-shirt. Gable's dialogue flowed smoothly after that. The sequence was so popular the males in the audience stopped buying undershirts, causing a massive drop in T-shirt sales.Another scene is the famous hitch-hiking sequence where the two are forced to stake a ride. After Peter is unsuccessful using his thumb, Ellie tries the approach by raising her skirt and showing some leg. A body double was used for the close-up. Colbert was appalled. "That's not my leg!" she exclaimed, and insisted her leg be used instead."It Happened One Night" is credited as cinema's first screwball comedy. Even though loose versions of the farcical genre had been around since Shakespeare, including 'As You Like It,' the format didn't really pick up steam until Columbia's film. Movie critic Andrew Sarris defined screwballs as "sex comedy without the sex." The commonality all the screwball comedies have is the quick-paced dialogue, with romantic relationships set in hilarious situations, and containing occasional class distinctions of the middle-class seen as 'heroes' while the upper-class members looking like saps.Even though "It Happened One Night" cleaned up at the box office in the secondary market, Colbert agreed with the sophisticated critics who gave a thumbs down to the movie. She was so sure she had no chance of winning the Academy Awards Best Actress, Colbert, despite her nomination, was seen boarding a train from Los Angeles to vacation in Phoenix during the evening of the ceremony. An Academy representative rushed to the station to inform her she had just won. Colbert went back to the Biltmore Hotel's gathering to accept the award. Film footage showing the evening's winners captures Colbert attired in traveling clothes."It Happened One Night" was the first to capture the 'Big Five" awards. The other two were 1975's "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" and 1991's "The Silence of the Lambs." Members of the American Film Institute rank the Capra film the 35th Best American Movie, the 8th Funniest, the 38th Most Passionate, the third Best Romantic Comedy, and nominated Ellie's quote, "Well, I proved once and for all that the limb is mightier than the thumb" as the one of the Best Quotes in Film. The motion picture is also included in the '1001 Movies You Must See Before You Die' reference book.

It happened, all right - happened to me. I LOVED this film, and I thought it was wonderful! Where do I begin? Well, it's still as fresh as a daisy today. Excellent performances from Clark Gable and Claudette Colbert, and easily worthy of "Best Actor/Actress" awards. Ditto for the script and direction! Best Picture of 1934? I haven't seen all the nominees yet, but this one is a shoe-in, I'd say. Absolute magic from Frank Capra, and you could have fooled me that this was the same man who directed IT'S A WONDERFUL LIFE (which I didn't much care for).Colbert plays the spoiled daughter of a stuffy socialite who decides to abandon her life of confinement. She winds up bumping into the tough Gable and from there, the sparks fly. Very humorous, and a great chemistry between the two lead performers. One of the best romantic comedies of all, and I'm prepared to call this easily one of the all-time greatest movies ever made too; it will certainly occupy a place on my own personal "100 Greatest Films" List (which I'm going to be working on over time).Oh yeah?? YEAH!
It Happened One Night is a classic rom-com that defined the genre. It's funny with good acting and a sharp script.

reviews.review_title: And it happens every time I see this movie....
reviews.content: Admiration for wonderful subtle acting, for the script, the wonderful cast of supporting characters,  It is nearly 70 years since this was made, and apart from the previously mentioned bonuses, there is also true Americana to be found, as in the term for "motel" was "auto camp" and a helicopter was called an "auto gyro".  The scene on the bus where "the daring young man on his flying trapeze" is sung has to be a classic. Clark and Claudette glow in this. Even though some of it is quite ahead of its time (sharing the room, the famous undershirt scene which caused undershirt sales to drop 50% in the year it was released)  the suggestions of hitting her to keep her in line are appalling today.  Roscoe Karns as Shapely gives a winning performance and nearly steals the movie.  I give it an 8 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: Practically flawless cinema from Frank Capra
reviews.content: Frank Capra's "It Happened One Night" may be his finest picture, which is somewhat surprising since it doesn't exhibit the trademark Capra style of later films like "Mr. Smith Goes to Washington" or "It's a Wonderful Life". No, "It Happened One Night" is an unabashed romantic comedy and one of the best (if not the very best) of all time.The story concerns a spoiled heiress (Claudette Colbert), on the run from her controlling father, who meets up with an unemployed newspaper reporter (Clark Gable) on a night bus to New York. They decide to work together to their mutual advantage but what starts out as a business arrangement gradually develops into something more.The film's embarrassment of riches begins with its stars. Not only do they deliver excellent performances individually but together they have wonderful chemistry. Gable's performance is probably the best of the two but both were deserving Oscar winners. Besides these two, the cast is uniformly solid, including supporting standouts Walter Connolly & Roscoe Karns.The film is distinguished as the first to win all five major Academy Awards. Besides the aforementioned Oscars for Best Actor & Best Actress, the film also took home Oscars for its adapted screenplay (by Robert Riskin) and direction (by Frank Capra) along with the prestigious Best Picture Oscar. Only three films have ever captured all five awards. Pretty elite company, to be sure, but well warranted given the quality of each contribution.In the end, "It Happened One Night" is a film that's practically without fault. Despite being over 75 years old it's still as vibrant as the day it was released. Without a doubt, it's a must-see for any self-respecting film fan.

As Hollywood increasingly turns out films that look like video games and dark, hyper-violent exercises in blood letting, I find myself increasingly interested in discovering the great classic of the past, and this film is certainly at the top of any list of classics. It's one of the last films of the pre-Code era, and as such delivers witty, adult, dialog and comic situations delivered by several great stars and character actors of the era.The story is a bit preposterous, with Claudette Colbert as the spoiled, sheltered, daughter of a protective multimillionaire and a young Clark Gable as the dashing but jaded young newspaper reporter who decides to help her escape her father's protective clutches in pursuit of a hot story. Madcap antics ensue, as they say, as the two may or may not fall in love with each other. It's all lightweight farce, but it's superbly well done, and a great piece of classic Hollywood entertainment.

It isn't any wonder why "It Happened One Night" struck such a chord with movie-goers in the depression-hit USA of the 1930's. Frank Capra's sparkling romantic comedy is just about as uplifting as any movie can possibly be. Whatever it is that makes a star a star, Clark Gable had it in spades more than any other leading man before or since, & how could Claudette Colbert, (or any other woman?), not fall in love with him. Against her father's (Walter Connolly) wishes Ellie Andrews (Colbert) has married newspaper magnate King Westley (Jameson Thomas) & after an argument she jumps her rich fathers yacht into the sea & swims to shore. She is wearing a long white silk gown & not carrying a handbag. Next we see her at Miami bus station purchasing a ticket to New York to be with her husband, complete with a new outfit & handbag! Even allowing for a few plot absurdities this is a movie with a big heart & is very entertaining. On board the bus she meets Peter Warne (Clark Gable) who is a newspaper reporter. When the bus makes a meal stop at Jacksonville Ellie has her handbag stolen leaving her with just 4 dollars. Peter now gets wind of who she is, the runaway daughter heiress of a millionaire father & he senses a good story. After they get back on board the bus Ellie sits next to a rather comical man named Oscar Shapeley (Roscoe Karns), who is an incessant chatterbox who has a habit of saying "believe you me". After getting tired of him she tells him, "Believe you me, you bore me to distraction". On this night there is a heavy rainstorm outside & the bus is forced to make an overnight stop. Peter hires out a chalet at a campsite & he tells the owner that he & Ellie are a married couple. When she protests he points out to Ellie that after the theft of most of her money they cannot afford "separate establishments". He attaches a length of rope across the centre of their chalet & drapes a blanket over it as a room divider which he calls "the walls of Jericho". "That I suppose makes everything quite alright" she tells him. Peter Warne now admits to her that he is a reporter & has latched on to Ellie Andrews because he senses a good story. He knows her real husband King Westley very well & tells her, "That guy is a phoney. If I were you I would take the next bus back to Miami". What follows is a movie that is chock full of memorably entertaining scenes & I guarantee that if anyone is feeling a bit low this film will improve their mood. Highly recommended.

Frank Capra's It Happened One Night is the little engine that could. It was a smallish romantic comedy produced on a modest budget from a minor studio. It would be a film, despite starring Clark Gable and Claudette Colbert, that would vanish as time progressed, right? Guess again! The movie happened to be the table-setter for a new kind of film, and it is a movie that resonates well with people, even to today's modern audience. Personally, I found much to enjoy. Despite my misgivings on the screwball genre, Capra gets it right. The situations are zany, fast, and witty. The performances are excellent, and Capra is on the top of his game following his usually formula in the world of comedy.The making of the film could have been its own film. This picture was produced by Columbia, which was seen as a minor picture at the time. Frank Capra lacked two major stars to appear. He previously worked with Claudette Colbert, but their experience together was negative, and she vowed never to work with him again. I guess a salary that is doubled would change minds. Because of how the studio system worked in the 1930's, actors were "owned" by individual studios. In Clark Gable's case, he worked for MGM. Rumor has it that he was punished by the studio and allowed Columbia to borrow him. Gable was apprehensive about the project and even showed up on the first day of set very drunk.The opening sequence sets the picture off with a bang. Ellie Andrews (Colbert) is a wealthy socialite who secretly married this aviator, Wesley. Her father, believing what is best for her, annulled her marriage. In anger, she jumps off the boat and goes ashore. Her father, Alexander (Walter Connolly) sends a private detective agency to find her. Ellie manages to stay one step ahead when she purchases a bus ticket. She sits next to a cynical journalist, Peter Warne (Gable). Warne manages to annoy her and ends up blackmailing her in order to force her to travel with him. Despite her original feelings, they begin to fall in love. But Ellie has reason to believe that Peter may be more into her father's $10,000 reward than her?It is well-known what an accidental pairing the teaming of Colbert and Gable was...but it worked in such a grand fashion. They both were fantastic as a whole and individually. Being such great actors, should we truly be surprised? The most famous scene in the movie is where Colbert shows off her leg to attract drivers. She was very hesitant at first, but she decided to do it anyway after she learned what Capra was going to do for Plan B. Gable really owned the role as the cynical reporter and he really elevated everything to another level in the film's end. Just watch and you shall see.It Happened One Night is the first picture to win the grand slam at the Academy Awards. It took home Best Picture, Director, Actor, and Actress. Colbert actually thought she wasn't going to win, so she did not attend the ceremony. The studio's head, Harry Cohn had to send someone to "drag her off the train" for her vacation. The film revolutionized the screwball genre, and it is the best film from the genre in my own humble opinion. Capra allowed his film to succeed on a quick, zany screenplay and wonderful, breezy performances. People back in the day were enamored with Gable's shirtless figure. Soon after the film was released, the Hays Code would come in effect which would not allow this. Anyhow, a funny, enjoyable picture with Frank Capra at the top of his game.My Grade: A-

It is a very rare thing when a light-hearted comedy, something that is quintessentially the stuff of a 'good movie,' breaches into that territory where the term 'good film' can also be applied, but Frank Capra's 1934 film It Happened One Night may be an exception. Today, most people know Capra solely for his rediscovered classic It's A Wonderful Life, made a dozen years later, but this film was his first stab at what most critics would label greatness. This is all the more interesting because the 1930s, with their still newly developed sound technology, were still a transition period, of sorts, with the over the top hammy expressionistic acting of the silent films still dominating more than the more subtle naturalism of later film eras.As a comedy, this is all the more striking, since there was not the manifest symbolism of some of the great silent film comedians, nor was there the social satire of the 1960s madcap comedies, nor those of Woody Allen's intellectualized Golden Era. Yet, Capra's film, aside from its fame as having lifted Columbia Pictures from the bottom of the film studio heap, and being the first film to win the Big Five Oscars in a single year- Academy Awards for Best Picture, Best Director, Best Adapted Screenplay, Best Lead Actor, and Best Lead Actress, is credited with being the first 'screwball comedy,' a subgenre of the romantic comedy, that flourished during the Great Depression and World War Two years. The films that this film kicked off all were romantic comedies, but the main focus of the films was on the frustrations the protagonists went through before inevitably ending up together in the end, rather than the stuff of pulp novels. Another aspect of this film, which makes it relevant today, is the brisk pace at which it was filmed, acted, and even edited. It is not as noticeable today, in Hollywood's caffeinated era, but compare it to any of a few dozen other films from that era and the difference is startling. there are a few cringe-inducing moments when the era is shown at its worst- with a portrayal of a Stepin Fetchit like black railroad character, but that's a minor cavil in an otherwise great comedy, and possibly great film. After all, greatness includes- it does not preclude, humanity, and Capra was as infected by the worst of his times as anyone. But what makes a man great, especially an artist, is the degree to which those times claw at him, and the percentage of times a man of his time becomes a man for all times. The same is true for his art, and this artist and his film pass both of those bars. It Happened One Night is still as funny as it ever was, and the fact that you will get a bit more is the type of bonus feature DVDs alone cannot provide.

Spoilers. Observations. Opinions.Clark and Claudette are excellent. I had put off seeing this film, because I thought that besides the leg-flashing hitchhiking part there must not be much interesting stuff in this movie.I finally watched it. It held my interest all the way through. It was funny and hilarious in places.Westley looked old enough to be Claudette's father. At the beginning, I thought Claudette was marrying her father's friend, another "old" man.Good to see Ward Bond, and an earlier version of tough looking Greyhound bus.Shapely was annoying, as he was supposed to be. The actor essayed the part well. Shapely believed it when Clark inferred that Shapely's children could end up being hurt. Hilarious! Tough guy Clark.Yes, I am interspersing the names of actors and characters.The father, in the end, paying off Westley, was a good move. This is part of the denouement of tying up the loose ends of the story. Clark, waiting in the car while the marriage ceremony was supposed to start, surely peeled off quite fast after that wonderful scene of Claudette running to meet him in her beautiful white wedding gown and veil.A singing Alan Hale was also hilarious. He was annoying to his passengers. He was the one whose car Claudette stopped when she raised up her skirt to her upper leg. Clark had failed in his ride-thumbing lessons; he couldn't flag down a car to save his neck.Clark pretended to be hard boiled, and Claudette pretended to be disinterested. Later, they had a meeting of the minds, er, hearts.This is a pre-code film. Pre-code films existed from near the beginning of sound films to around mid 1934. Pre-code allowed more sexuality, sexual innuendoes, adultery, violence, etc., than were allowed after this period. Church groups, moralists and Hollywood censors took care of that. Some pre-code things I noticed: motel managers wondered if sleepers Clark and Claudette were married. Claudette removed her clothes down to her slip. Clark showed his bare chest to Claudette. The beds were separate, and separated by a blanket draped over a rope, but they were in the same bedroom. Even Claudette raising her skirt up high on her thigh got a lot of the audience's attention when this film was new.

The original rom-com that is still ruling the commercial rom-com genre with all of the tropes created in it. It's an entertaining film that still has its charm after all these years. But it has aged poorly in a lot of facets too. The regressive stereotypes are a bit much in today's age. Even if we consider the age of the film, it's just annoying and distracting all the time with its characters' outdated crappy behaviour. It's still a fun film that can be remembered for being the first in a lot of things but not one of the greatest films in a long shot. Iconic moments alone doesn't make a film great, it should stand the test of time. This film stands the test of time in certain aspects and fails in certain others. Still, the moments like the hitch-hikers leg, the bride running away etc makes it a classic worth noting.

It Happened One Night (1934), was a film of firsts. It is an example of early romantic comedy in film. It was the type of rom-com, that influenced many films that came after it. It took that genre and galvanized it, so it would become a staple genre for the next century. Also, this film capitalizes on a few other sub-genres. This film is an off-shoot of the sub-genre known as the "buddy" film, only in this case it is between a man and a woman, from two completely different backgrounds, coming together to help each other. They also capitalize on the classic sub-genre known as the "chase" film, where our two characters take us on a journey across the country, as they flee from the other characters, to reach their final goals.The plot of the film revolves around a rich socialite, the daughter of rich businessman named Alexander Andrews (Walter Connolly), Ellen, who rebels against her father and marries a spoiled-rich, fortune-hunter, named King Westley (Jameson Thomas). Ellen (Claudette Colbert), escapes from her father's home and ends up in Jacksonville, where she meets a man, an unemployed reporter, named Peter Warne (Clark Gable). He tells her that he will help her get to New York City to be with Westley, in order to grab a scoop of a story. If she doesn't cooperate he'll turn her over to her father. So, off on their adventure to New York City, they go.This film came out at a very interesting time in Hollywood's history. It was a post-depression era film, part of the early-talkie era and a pre-code Hollywood film (although the censorship-code started to take hold by 1935, so this is at the tail-end of that moment in film history). The use of sound in film was becoming more streamlined and much more crisper. This one uses all the techniques and talents that made early sound film so groundbreaking.This film completes its greatness by winning the Best Picture Award at the Oscars in 1934. This film won all of the big five awards that year. It has those classic moments that made this film wonderful to watch. From the hitchhiking lesson, to the "Flying Trapeze", sung on the bus, to sleeping in a hay field and dividing the room up with a rope and a blanket. It has the right amount of comedy, drama, mood, sexual tension, sights, songs and sounds, that make it a near-perfect film.Clark Gable and Claudette Colbert earned their Oscar wins, by convincingly giving us performances that still hold up today. His portrayal is right on the numbers. He doesn't come off as an over-emphasized 1930s cliché. His character does work throughout the ages. He's nice, but tough. He's sly, but also ignorant. He can be slick, but also look like a clown. His resourcefulness is lost on her though, because she is so prone to being waited on by others, that she doesn't see the extraordinary lengths he goes through to please her.I also want to emphasize the conditions these actors had to work under when they made these films so long ago. Today actors have huge campers they can wait in until filming starts. They have more protections for their safety today. They have a team of people around them catering to their every need. Technologies, communication and transportation is much more accessible today. When you watch these older films, visualize yourself and your friends today going out for a film shoot, in the rain, mud, cold, with limited resources and a couple of vehicles, that barely go over 35 miles an hour. That is what it was like, filming these huge Hollywood productions, back in its early days. It's these great moments, involving the whole process of the thing, that makes a film like this even greater.8.9 (A- MyGrade) = 9 IMDB.

reviews.review_title: Like a really old Overboard w/o amnesia
reviews.content: I loved this movie, it reminded me of an older version of Overboard. Rich girl has to live poorly for awhile, only no amnesia. Highly recommend!

Boy meets girl.They come from different roads in life and don't see eye to eye at first,but gradually they fall in love.This is a theme we have seen again and again throughout cinema history.Sometimes it is done well and sometimes..not so much.This is definitely the film that started it all,and the mold was broken.This is by far the best romantic comedy that I have ever seen.Claudette Colbert may not have thought so,for it has been said that she said to a friend after completing production that she had just finished "the worst film I have ever done."Surely she changed her tone when they placed the Best Actress Oscar in her hands.The screen chemistry between Colbert and Gable was right on the money.It is THE laugh out loud romantic classic.

I will soon be riding a bus of my own sometime. If Clark Gable as Peter could find a rich young lady who could fall in love with his witty, charming, eccentric and sometimes rough around the edges personality, then maybe I can nab myself a girlfriend by the end of this trip. I just hope my experience lines up more with Peter's than that of Roscoe Karns' Shapely, but I'm not much of a talker like him, so I *should* be in the clear.

"It Happened One Night" is one of the oldest films that I've ever watched, so I understand that this is from a bygone era which may not be totally relatable today and that talking movies at that time were still in their infancy so it's not really fair to analyze this film with decades of hindsight. But on the other hand, I am watching this in 2022 in the context of all the other films that I've seen and as such I rate "It happened One Night" a 5/10. It is a decent movie but somewhat plodding and not real inspiring or moving. It is similar to modern made-for-tv romance movies in that way. As I've said before, I give these sorts of films a 5/10. Though it is not excessively dated, that is not really the problem, it's just not that exceptional a movie; it is overrated, but not a bad film, just ok.

This may be but a wish-fulfillment farce, but well-crafted all the same. It is never dull, and the story keeps you off-balance so the viewer never can really be sure how things will turn out.A spoiled daughter of a very rich father, tiring of his gilded cage, finally runs off to elope with a daredevil aviator, who is in New York. The father hires a slew of detectives to locate her, but she manages to get on a bus with a reporter who has heard about her situation and wants a big story to boost his career. With that purpose, he helps the daughter on her way to New York, but plenty of things go wrong along the way. And to make matters worse, the father decides to allow the marriage to take place-but complications ensue from that.Great character interaction and acting not only between the two leads, but between each of them as well as side characters make the story exciting, and the atmosphere of a dull, irritating bus ride and later running through the countryside is perfectly conveyed. Arguably one of the greatest of Frank Capra's movies.

reviews.review_title: See It for Capra, Gable and Colbert
reviews.content: To modern sensibilities, "It Happened One Night" is a tame cliché of a love story. Although tabbed as a classic "screwball comedy," in fact it lacks the essentials of that genre. It is neither as funny nor as romantic as the best of the screwball comedies. The end is visible from the beginning, and the road from start to finish doesn't travel a route that is particularly entertaining. Nonetheless, this is a landmark film of the 1930's and it deploys three of the great talents of that era: Frank Capra as director and Clark Gable and Claudette Colbert as the two hostile personalities who eventually fall in love. I never thought much of Gable when I was young but my mother often said he was the handsomest man alive. Colbert also pales alongside contemporary sexpots yet she was considered one of the most beautiful of the stars (back in the days when Stars were Stars). And Capra was considered a master movie-maker in his day. Although tame by contemporary standards, "It Happened One Night" is worth viewing as a milestone of an earlier era. Bearing in mind the limited technical resources available at the time and the no-sex code imposed by the Hays Office, I think it's worth 8 out of 10.

We all know that love works in mysterious ways: sometimes all we need is a little push from outside, a swim through the river, a ride in a car or even one night in the room divided with the sheet to find out so much more about yourself than you thought you knew up to that point. All of the worthy things happen to us unintentionally one way or the other and who knows maybe the person sitting on a bus next to you is destined for a longer ride."It happened one night" is Frank Capra's Oscar-winning Best Picture of 1934 and it stars rough, tough but handsome enough Clark Gable and charming Claudette Colbert. The movie tells a story of a spoiled little girl of a rich father whose only purpose in life is to contradict him because he doesn't allow her to do what she wants, and she wants stupid things. But even stupid things can become the smartest decision you have ever made. She runs away from home to be with her "safe" person of interest and meets this fellow who is a complete opposite - he's rude and impolite, he speaks his mind about everything, he can't stand her kind of people but (and here's a mysterious part) he loves her anyway.No matter how different or how incompatible two people can seem it is their feelings that have the real value. If they are able to co-exist and not kill each other, they care for each other and do not want to be anywhere else than right beside one another - that's it. It happened. And usually it happens so fast you wouldn't even notice it until you're full speed ahead in it.Clark gives one of the best performances in his career whereas Claudette is absolutely gorgeous in her role; you just cannot take your eyes off of their pair. Frank has done an incredible job and starting with "It happened one night" his career took off like a rocket for the stardom where it stayed for a long time and for ever in my heart.

reviews.review_title: Its Excellence Overcomes Being Slightly Dated
reviews.content: "It Happened One Night" is a clever, warm comedy which mixes in a hint of attitude. The female lead character, Ellie Andrews, is in her early twenties and lives in an old-fashioned U.S.A. where women are invested with significance by the males who govern and guide them. Her wealthy father has detained Ellie against her will on his boat, because he wants to annul her recent marriage to a man he despises. Ellie escapes and hits the road with fired reporter Peter Warne (Clark Gable), both endeavoring to get Ellie back together with her husband.The night scenes are beautiful, with light luminously dappling the darkness - the night crossing of the stream and the bedding down beside the hay carts are awesome.Director Frank Capra eloquently brings to life inclusion in God's vast family by portraying a makeshift community of bus passengers joining in song.Yes. This film is somewhat dated by the inferior status of women and the two-bed accommodations for a supposedly married couple; but to be fair to the writers and Mr. Capra, they worked under the intimidation of the Hays Office restrictions: a ludicrous and un-American brand of censorship which was in the vigor of new enforcement when this picture was made. Keeping this in mind, the viewer can see that the writers and director managed to cleverly slip some of the sensuality of real life into the movie.Despite any minor qualms, "It Happened One Night" is a delightful comedy which achieves excellence and is well worth your time.

Watching this movie, made me merge my mind back into the 1930s and wish that I was Clark Gable!!  This movie, with the great Frank Capra directing, is a wonderful story about a romance that on paper just shouldn't be. Claudette Colbert plays the young daughter of a rich Wall Street businessman who swims away from her father while traveling on a boat.  She meets up with Gable's character, Peter Warren, on a bus set to go to New York City.  That's where the fun begins!  The chemistry between Gable and Colbert is there.  They feed off of each other and have an enjoyable time making this movie.  You can just tell.  It's easy to see why this movie won the 5 big Academy Awards!

I love director Frank Capra's work, but hadn't seen this until now. I'm glad I did.Here's my breakdown:STORY:
In retrospect, this story isn't all that unusual, but there's enough good story to give it a nice balance:
> Conflicting personalities
> Suspense and levity
> Romance built on fidelity
> A predictable end**My only complaint with the storyACTING:
Normally, I'm not a fan of stars because most become obese with pride and self-obsession. Gable
was (is) an example of that, but his ability to be so natural on screen is compelling. I would compare him
and Cary Grant, but Grant not only had a single gear, he was so arrogant and demeaning. Yes, Gable
doesn't treat women much better, but his natural style is far more genuine than Grant's pretense.Colbert did a great job, and showed why women normally out-perform men in acting. The flexibility and
range are much wider, and Colbert exercises these traits well here. Comparing her to Jean Arthur in
another Capra film "You Can't Take It with You" (1938), Arthur has a much softer and wider range.But both deliver perfectly on their respective roles.ENTERTAINMENT:
Moderate to high value (for those who love classics)TEMPO:
Good paceCINEMATOGRAPHY:
For the era, I was impressed (even with the sets)MUSIC / SOUND:
Limited, which was just about rightDIRECTING / WRITING:
Director: There's a hand full of brilliant directors: Capra, Hitchcock, Wyler, Wilder ... and a few contemporary
ones. But Capra will always be among the "giants" of film directing.Writers: Riskin has written some good story, e.g. "Lady for a Day " (1933) and this. No doubt there are others, but
I thought "Lost Horizon" (1937) was awful. Frankly, I dislike Gary Cooper's "acting," so I've not see some of Riskin's
other work for that reason.Is it a good film? YesShould you watch this once? YesRating: 7.5.

reviews.review_title: Classic Comedy About Sheltered Female and Strong Male=TNT
reviews.content: This script by Robert Riskin I find to be filled with excellent dialogue; This is an unpretentious but very idea-level social satire, involving the unlikely pairing of no-nonsense Clark Gable with classically-trained charismatic Claudette Colbert. The second unlikeliness about the film is the princess-like Colbert, being barred by her magnate father from consummating a secret marriage, jumping off the yacht where she is being confined and ending up being spotted by newsman Gable. He is in fact portrayed as the usual late-twenties hard-drinking no-nonsense reporter sort with three exceptions--he is adventurous, able to get along and function effectively at all levels of society even during the Depresssion, and he is working in a profession where there is no job-level between managing editor and field reporter; this all leaves him frustrated by dull or routine assignments but wanting to investigate and do something important in the world. Only the wealth of Colbert's father qualifies her as important. Once he befriends her, and agrees to get her where she wants to go, the added complication comes from their attraction for one another, a slowly growing and smoldering subtext to what they actually do. He disapproves of her; she disapproves of him. He represents, it appears to me, reality--what she has been denied every bit as much as any European princess ("The Princess Comes Across", "Roman Holiday") has been denied it; and he is a natural leader shut out from the upper levels of society and thus denied also; and he is the natural leader/mental aristocrat by ability denied her worlds of unobstructed goal-setting, doing one's one desires and not having to be disbarred from anything. As no one I know has noticed, then, this is a European story-line grafted onto a supposedly classless U.S., every bit as much so as is "Destry Rides Again" or "Roman Scandals". That I suggest is the secret to "It Happened One Night" and its strong story-line; it is a film about Gable's personal purpose of doing a good story for his career's sake and having it turned upside down by his falling in love with what Colbert ought-to-be, could be, and is becoming. The "Walls of Jericho" business involving the erecting of a curtain so Colbert will feel safe spending the night with Gable is a charming device for comedic purposes, as is Gable's removing his shirt as a symbol of reality-sexuality being offered to Colbert, the last thing she immediately wants to deal with. In another sense, the Walls are protecting him, the realist, from immediately having to deal with her higher-value-sexual meaning rather than her story-value to him as a reporter. The cleverness of the dialogue, picaresque adventures, human encounters and interactions depicted in the movie all magnify its importance again. And the fact that these are all beautifully presented by director Frank Capra and his technicians further increases their ability to affect an audience. The couple's different ways of handling people, the dunking of a donut, and the classic triumph of the bared female leg (hers) over hitchhiking expertise (his) at promoting them a ride become symbols of the natural triumphing over the artificial. over "barriers". And when the time comes for Ellie Andrews (Colbert) to decide whether she wants to stay married to one King Westley or divorce or marry Peter Warne (Gable), we the viewers have been well-informed as to what decision she will be making. This is a screwball-type comedy due to the unpredictable reactions of many persons to the Depression's unnatural restraints and emergencies. The basic situation--the princess-cheerleader female and the rough-hewn-commoner male has been carried out many times, but never with more success since the film's release; but this is essentially a European plot line grafted onto a U.S. stature-through-ability individualism; this is why so many attempts at this formula have failed, I suggest; because the formula was not understood, and because the united States has been increasingly unAmerican since 1902, particularly since 1937. The other interesting and important aspect I find as a writer is that Gable does not know who this waif is at the beginning; so we find that Gable's character is a commoner who deserves to be an important man, a first-rate newspaperman frustrated by his inability to chart his own course, a man who likes people who lives in a rough, noir-like environment, and a man who likes women and wants an equal but has to play mentor to a desirable woman only slowly realizing her potential. This is the "ice-goddess" aspect of the rich explored in "The Phildaelphia Story" by Philip Barry; Gable's problem is that of the great man stuck in a tsar-ridden society, familiar from "Holiday", "The Big Sleep" and "The Fountainhead" among others. The film I find is a delight; its dated aspects are those of its technologically backward period only. Its strengths appear to me to be derived from its honest plot and many interesting characters. Both leads are self-regulating; he lives by a moral code, and during the film she discovers the need for one. They seem to be an excellent match, when all is said and done. The evils of the Depression, which socialist Capra might have stressed even more than he does, are used very cleverly here as a background to the personal self-discovery mutual story-line. This is a well-photographed and artistic effort, I suggest, but nothing as stylish as Capra's later efforts. Cinematography by Joseph Walker, art direction by Stephen Goosson, and Robert Kalloch's costumes, with brief music only being provided all add to the realistic sense of the two character's descent from riches or daily reality and their immersion in the wider meaning of a nation in social upheaval and economic distress. In the cast the viewer should note Walter Connolly as Colbert's exasperated banker father, Roscoe Karns, Ward Bond, Alan Hale, Arthur Hoyt, Jameson Roberts, Harry Hume, Milton Kibbee and many more persons effective in brief parts. This is a well-designed movie, very deserving of its popularity.

reviews.review_title: "What makes you so disgustingly cheerful this morning?"
reviews.content: Director Frank Capra's "It Happened One Night" (1934) was deemed "culturally, historically, and aesthetically significant" by the Library of Congress in 1993, and for that it was preserved in the National Film Registry. It is an honor few films have received, considering only 550 out of the hundreds of thousands of films America has produced since film's birth long ago. This is rightfully so, as the film is a masterpiece on many levels and despite being nearly eighty years old watching it today it still doesn't feel dated at all. Its humor is golden, there being so many classic lines I've heard them quoted so many times in other productions and in everyday life even. Not only that but it was a blue print for future films of a similar genre, the romantic comedy everyone's come to know and love, and its influence is unmistakable as well as undeniable. The film encompasses many aspects of the classic screwball comedy that was prominent in the 30s and 40s. Though elements of the subgenre have survived on for years in modern comedy, the screwball comedy of the early twentieth century represented a specific point in American history. Take for instance Claudette Colbert's character, Ellie. Besides being beautiful, she is intelligent, especially compared to the minor male characters. We see this in the opening scenes and one of our initial reactions may be to think of her as nothing more than a spoiled brat. However, the clever writing uses her somewhat awkward and clumsy nature amongst the everyday people and bus travelers not only as comedy, but as a way to draw sympathy for the character. We soon see that she is alone in her plight, and so arrives the charming Peter Warren, played by Clark Gable. Peter Warren appears and quickly distinguishes himself from the other male characters in that he is not only intelligent, but he's a man of honor and dignity. Not only that, he's street smart and humble compared to Ellie's would be husband. Consider the well-played foil of how Peter is on a simple bus, in sharp contrast to the groom who arrives at his wedding in a plane of all things. It is on the bus where the majority of the character interaction takes place. The two seemingly opposite personalities are brought together by fate, another one of the trademarks of screwball comedy that became a principle of romantic comedy as a whole. Throughout the film, one hears dialogue in rather a series of quips almost, the comedic insults and quirks of the characters. You see this with many of them, but it is strongest with the two star crossed lovers.That is one of the beauties of screwball comedy. This "sex comedy without sex" achieves its sexual tension without being lewd at all. Despite the lack of today's raunchy style, the dialogue is so rich, and the actors so talented with lines, you can feel the attraction building. Before it even reaches the dénouement, you can hardly notice how much closer the characters have become due to its sublime subtlety. Romantically speaking, the hay scene is the high note, as we finally see the boiling romance between the characters that they previously denied or really had no intention of. But also, and perhaps for memorabilia and sentimental laughs really, would be the hitch-hiking scene. It's not just incredibly hilarious, but Ellie finally proves her worth to Peter who previously had cared for her almost as if she were a helpless damsel. It's brilliant characterization at work. The mise-en-scene of this film is another one of its main attractions. On one level, it represents the social status differences and qualities of the character. In many shots of Ellie's father (Walter Colbert), we see the fine wine and other assorted alcohols. In sharp contrast, the first time we see Peter he's drinking out of a bottle in a telephone booth. The remarkable beauty of the film's artistic mise-en-scene though comes out in its night scenes, especially in the rain. The camera and lighting really illuminates the characters in those scenes. It makes them stand out amongst the others as if they weren't even there. As time goes on, night after night, the two literally and emotionally draw closer to one another." It Happened One Night" is a masterpiece on many aspects. It is a classic that represents the birth of a genre and a picture of human emotion. Alas all that, it is a frozen moment in history, giving illusion to a time that has been forgotten by some. Taking all that into account, along with the majestic authenticity of the glorious black-and-white days, it truly stands the test of time.

A beautifully structured script by Robert Riskin strains credulity at times, but Riskin shrewdly and astutely calculates what the audience wants and always delivers. Even when we know what we're going to get, he manages the suspenseful buildup masterfully. With Frank Capra's expert staging and direction, Clark Gable and Claudette Colbert deliver performances that endear themselves to us forever. This great comedy came along at the perfect historical moment, when audiences felt rich folks needed to be taken down a peg. Or two. Riskin, Capra and Hollywood at their best.

reviews.review_title: wonder why they called it, it happened one night
reviews.content: It Happened One Night is one of the only three movies since the commencement of the Academy Awards to have been able to win all five major Academy Awards (Best Picture, Best Director, Best Actor, Best Actress, and Best Screenplay), a feat that would not be matched until One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest in 1975 and of cause latter on in 1991, Anthony Hopkins The Silence of the Lambs followed suit.Here is a romantic comedy as raw as they come giving you a thrill as you watch two people miss matched from the start found a way to fall in love and tour America on their way to New York. The funny thing about the movie is the name which says, "It happened one night" when actually in the movie's story it actually went on for more than a night.The movie plot is about Ellie Andrews (Claudette Colbert) who has been whisked away by her father in his yacht to keep her away from her new husband King Westley. Ellie then jumps ship, swim to shore and heads off to New York to meet with King Westley. On her way she meets a reporter Peter Warne (Clark Gable) and both started as an unsuitable pair that grew to be lovers.Both Colbert and Gable felt the movie was not going to be good enough and gave Capra a lot of bull. Even the movie's iconic scene where Colbert lifted up her skirt to stop a car during the hitchhiking scene, was not so easy to film for Capra as Colbert refused to do the scene claiming it was not lady like, but upon seeing a body double do it, she later changed her mind and did it herself.Although picking up slow, the movie later became one the biggest hits for the studio and the thing is that at the end the movie cleared the Academy Awards and both Gable and Colbert were better off. Colbert is known to have told a friend, "I just finished the worst picture in the world." She boycotted the Academy Awards when she got a nomination believing she will not win, but she was called back to come pick up her award.Here is a movie that actually makes you smile all the way through, although like the actors themselves upon initial siting of the film you can be turned off thinking this is heading nowhere, but be patient the movie has all the familiar scenes that we see in the movies today (all taken from this old classic). This old classic is tagged the 46th greatest film in the last 100 years in the AFI's 100 Years... 100 Movies (10th Anniversary Edition).It Happened One Night is a nice DVD for one to place on the shelf.www.lagsreviews.com

The genre of 'Romantic comedy' is generally scoffed at and looked down upon by critics and many viewers nowadays. This is mainly because of the mechanical way in which a huge number of them have been produced over the years and unfortunately, there is a distinct lack of creativity and artistic input apparent in most of them. Although the prejudice that some people have against the films categorised in this genre is justified due to recent releases, but one has to acknowledge the fact that a number of great and incredibly influential films also are romantic comedies. The film that is widely regarded as the one that pretty much single-handedly started it all, is Frank Capra's 'It Happened One Night'. It was the first Screwball Comedy and it is very easy to see the way it influenced subsequent films.'It Happened One Night' is a film set in the Depression Era. It hints at the struggles that ordinary American people faced at the time. However, the film never really tackles it head on and in a way must have offered the viewers of the time a nice escape from reality and an escape from the horrors of their financial problems. The film explores the class distinctions of society. We get to see two individuals belonging to different classes and financial backgrounds get together and go on a journey. We see the character of Peter showcase his disdain and prejudice against the haves of the society. We also see how Ellie being a rich sheltered socialite finds it difficult to completely fit in with Peter and his ways initially. The gender politics in the film is an interesting element. On one hand, there certainly are aspects of it like Ellie needing Peter's help for everything, or some of Peter's aggressive remarks towards Ellie that can make the film look a bit dated, but from another angle it is a bit progressive too. We see at the beginning that Ellie is being almost suffocated and imprisoned by her father. Capra gives us a good understanding of how oppressed she clearly feels and the whole affair with King Westley is nothing but an attempt to break away from the shackles.The film is very charming and funny. Clarke Gable puts on an utterly charismatic performance. He exudes charm and charisma and Claudette Colbert holds her own brilliantly. The chemistry and the wit involved in the scenes between them to a great extent makes the film. Robert Riskin's script is rich with witty, snappy and sharp dialogue. There are singular examples of brilliant scenes that stick out over the others which are extremely funny even today like the piggyback scene, the hitchhiking scene, etc. to name a few. The film pretty much set the template for the trope of the two leads hating each other at the beginning and then slowly developing feelings for each other. We see this transition take place slowly and gradually. There are three major scenes involving just the two of them having a conversation before going off to sleep which can be used to notice the changes and developments that take place in the way they perceive each other over the course of their journey.This was made when the silent films were starting to go out of fashion, and one can see how much the camera work is reminiscent of the silent films of the era. The camera is not very mobile and the movement of the camera is kept to a minimum. However there is one specific moment of bravura camera movement in the scene where the camera tracks sideways from left to right to follow Ellie as she heads to the cottage shower while being noticed by the working class people in the locality. Another very important aspect of Capra's direction is his lack of the use of music. Films of the later 30s and early 40s were famous for being a bit drowned in music. But Capra uses the music in a very discreet way. Some of the most important scenes in terms of character development is accompanied by nothing but the sound of crickets chirping in the background. But I couldn't say the film blew me away and I'm sure that's because of the fact that I was already expecting a lot of the twists and story elements that were going to transpire as they have been repeated to death over the years in other films. The last 20 minutes of the film I felt were a bit flat. Another example of a film which left me a bit underwhelmed because of the tropes being used and reused in later films was 'Double Indemnity'. I know maybe this criticism is a bit unfair, but I generally tend to judge a film solely based on whether it worked for me or not irrespective of when it was released and I'm afraid 'It Happened One Night' doesn't completely hold up.Having said that it is still a charming, funny film with charismatic performances. There are a number of scenes of genuine comedy littered throughout the film. But the last 20 minutes left me a bit underwhelmed.

reviews.review_title: Classic comedy romance starring the amazing Clark Gable
reviews.content: This old black and white Frank Capra classic must surely have set the standard for the romantic comedy, perhaps even been the first of this genre. It stars Claudette Colbert and my favourite actor from that era, the handsome Clark Gable, who fall in love in the midst of an entertaining set of screwball adventures, all the while exchanging assorted witty banter.The story revolves around a spoiled heiress, Ellie Andrews, who marries a fortune hunter named King Westley against the wishes of her father, who has the marriage annulled before it can be consummated. Ellie runs off and boards a bus where she meets reporter Peter Warne, who recognizes her. He gives her a choice, either give him an exclusive story and he will reunite her with King or he will reveal her whereabouts to her father and collect the reward. Ellie agrees to give the story and various adventures ensue, during the course of which the pair develop a mutual attraction.This movie has two main claims to fame, other than its incredible male star! The first is the hitchhiking scene in which Peter tries unsuccessfully to thumb a ride, turned down by car after car. Then Ellie lifts her skirt to reveal a shapely leg and...you guessed it, the next driver slams on his brakes!The other is the famous Walls of Jericho scene, which is my lingering memory of this tale. Peter and Ellie are obliged to share a motel room for the night, surely quite risqué for that era! However, in order to maintain the proper decorum for an unmarried couple, a blanket is hung up sort of clothesline style to separate the two sleepers. Oh, the Good Old Days when couples weren't having sex within the first fifteen minutes of the movie! Now I won't give any spoilers, but will those walls of Jericho ever come tumbling down?

reviews.review_title: What Is the Deal With Donut Dunking?!
reviews.content: It Happened One Night was my first exposure to what I now consider to be my favourite genre of film, the screwball comedy. I'll never forget the feeling of exuberance at watching Clark Gable run to his boss at the newspaper to pitch a story about how he's fallen in love with a princess, such energy, such emotion; I had never felt such a way from watching a movie before. It Happened One Night is the famous and most widely seen film of its genre and I believe it deserves such an accolade; something unforgettable is happening in every scene, whether funny or tender, jam-packed little details to spot on every viewing. It Happened One Night along with Twentieth Century gave birth to the screwball comedy, but it isn't the only sub-genre it set a standard for. The runaway princess movie, the road movie and the newspaper comedy all owe their debts to it.In his opening scene, Clark Gable is introduced as the king; couldn't be more adapt. Watching the movie closely I can say that everything this man says is pure gold from his art of donut dunking, art of clothes removal, the different methods hitchhike signaling and his wall of Jericho. Then it dawned on me just how Seinfeldian this movie is. Much of Clark Gable's dialogue in this movie could be a Jerry Seinfeld stand up routine. It's easy to see how many screwball comedies have influenced modern day sitcoms; all that's missing is the laugh track.Claudette Colbert is one of the most famous incumbents of The Gable Treatment; what I like to call the macho manner in which Gable treats his leading ladies. Of course for any other actor to have this characteristic they would be an unlikable brute, but because it's Gable it works. I also have to ask did the scene in which Gable eats a raw carrot while attempting to hitch-hike with his usual confidence and cockiness inspire Bugs Bunny? Ah Gable, has never ever existed a more charismatic human being?

It Happened One Night is regarded as the first screwball romantic comedy, if not one of the first, in film history. In 2023, it still makes people laugh and fall in love. It is a movie that is way ahead of its time.I'm not really into romance movies unless it makes me laugh, or has a historical backdrop like the Titanic, or has won many awards that makes it enough to get me intrigued and see what the fuss is about.It Happened One Night tells the story of an heiress who runs away from his multi-million dollar worth of a father. While running away, he meets a hostile newspaper reporter.Clark Gable and Claudette Colbert had an amazing chemistry. The movie did not fail to make me laugh, and it has scenes that are radical by the standards of that time. That ending, too, is perfect. Funny, Claudette Colbert herself hated making the movie, and was shocked when it won all five of the major awards at the Oscars, including one for herself as Best Actress and another for Best Picture.It Happened One Night is definitely a classic gem that must be treasured even in the times to come.

reviews.review_title: The First Movie to Win the Main Five Oscars !
reviews.content: I don't care so much about the Oscars .. but in the old days there was less robbing and cheating than today .. it is just honorary prize to the movies and not a certain indicators to show a movie supremacy whatsoever .. anyway, sometimes the Oscars are given honestly to the best achievement in any category .. like this movie which was the first to win the five main Oscars (( best actor in leading role, best actress in leading role, best script, best picture & best director )) .. only three movies won the five main Oscars (Silence of the Lambs, One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest & It Happened One Night) .. I found it the 2nd best of the three after "Silence of the Lambs" and I don't think " One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" deserved even to get some nominations. It is one of the legendary Frank Capra's first and best movies .. it is one of the best road movies of all-time. Claudette Colbert & Clark Gable made a very good couple.The music .. the acting .. the atmosphere is amazing and very superior to its time. I do not know what else to say .. I need to re-watch it again.Two thumbs up! .. one of the best movies in the 1930s .. one of Capra's best .. and possibly the best road movie ever.

reviews.review_title: Frank Capra at his very best
reviews.content: "It Happened One Night" is one of my all-time favorite movies, easily my favorite romantic comedy, and often credited with being the first "screwball comedy" in Hollywood history, a genre with which Preston Sturges would be most associated. While it may not be the earliest "romantic comedy," the movie did establish several industry "firsts": first to win the "top 5" Academy Awards including Best Picture (which has only happened two more times since then, in 1975 for "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" and 1991 for "The Silence of the Lambs"); first to win the Oscar for Best Picture & also to be named best by the National Board of Review. And all this by a movie that neither of its leads wanted to be in, were the director's first (or even his third) choice, nor thought after completing it was any good or would be successful. But Gable and Colbert were dead wrong, and Capra was right. I am not a huge fan of all Frank Capra's films, some of which strike me as corny and too emotionally manipulative. But he sure nailed this one! I'd give it a 9/10.

This film probably started the whole romantic genre. Gable and Colbert are sweet together, and the ending is fabulous! Unusual that it won all the major Oscars since it is a comedy, but it still works 70 years later. A must have for any classic movie romantic comedy lover..

Watching this movie, made just 5 years after the invention of sound in the movies, is watching the invention of movie making itself.With only 5 years experience in scripts for "talkies", this script is outstanding. It is not a stage play on celluloid, the dialogue is wonderfully emotive and not descriptive. The tone is light but not too light. There is enough space between the word and the role to create a character.What is more remarkable is the absence of sentiment. A lot of movies from that era "create" the moment for the audience: the music decides when the viewer needs to be scared, to be touched, to cry. Here there is no such forced reaction. And yet the order of the events keeps us interested, keeps us with both lead characters and their emotions.The funny thing is that it is a comedy, often referred to as the first screwball comedy, but it has no jokes. There are witty lines, of course, but no "laugh or I'll shoot"-remarks. The funniest bits are when Claudette Colbert proves how to get a free ride by showing her leg and the driver who comments on everything by making a song of it. Those moments could be clichés now, but at the time they were original and fresh, and even to a 21st century audience, used to so many comic situations, those scenes are still funny and touching .The sympathy and understanding that this movie show for humans in general gives the viewer the same sympathy and understanding. How not to be touched by the scene in the bus where people are singing a song they all know, and where strangers take turns singing the different verses. To see such community feeling in an era that was struck by poverty and despair is heartwarming.Both leads achieve to be likable and believable just by portraying a round character. A film that celebrates humanity, extraordinarily simple but touchingly effective, and that in 1934!

This movie is a personal favorite of mine.  I am reminded of the appeal to me, when watching it as a child.  Yes, the movie was made around 40 years before I was born... but the feel is all so clear.  There is a sense of being alone, where no one truly knows you.  A sense of adventure, and discovery, wit, and romance... that always brings me back.Now it's plain to see, Cary Grant and Claudet Colbert are wonderful together. I am reminded of growing up with my sister, and feeling  seperated from family and society, like the two actors in this film, on a sort of journey thru blindness, to find your way home again.

I have watched many modern colorful and whimsical movies, looking back at the 1934 black and white movies, I thought I could not enter into the movie without patience, I did not expect to be immersed in the first act, feeling the characters of that era, walking in At the corner of that era, riding the traffic of that era, listening to the stories of that era. Although it was only a black-and-white picture, it seemed that I had returned to that calm era, and I could feel the green grass, the breeze blowing, and the beautiful wind at that time. After a careful taste, it is endless.At the beginning of the story, a stern and powerful father prevented her daughter Ellie from looking for true love. In this way, it seems that the father is the villain of the play. While avoiding her father 's eyes, Ellie went to New York to find his true love Wesley. At this time, in the car, I met the petty gentleman Pete who was in conflict with his boss. Pete's nature was naturally disgusted by the silly white sweet Allie. reviews.review_title: Lays the Groundwork for Future Rom-Coms
reviews.content: The daughter of a millionaire (Claudette Colbert) runs away from her father (Walter Connolly) and is aided by a disgruntled reporter (Clark Gable) as she travels across the country.This movie is quite good. Clark Gable is excellent, as always, playing the blunt straight man Peter Warne. Colbert is also very good as the spoiled daddy's girl Ellen Andrews. A standout side character for me was Shapely (Roscoe Karns), an annoying man who hits on Ellen during her travels.I think it's very well-made, especially for the time. It's a typical "rich person falls in love with working class" story. It's got a good ending. It's worth checking out, but it's a bit older now. It's got a lot going for it, but I personally don't think that it has a lot of staying power as a "classic" film.

One of the great movies of all time.  It's everything the younger generation (of which I am a member) wouldn't expect from a movie five years OLDER than "Gone with the Wind" and "The Wizard of Oz."Razor-sharp dialogue; wonderful, memorable characters; and the first movie to win all 5 major Oscars-- Best Picture, Director, Actor, Actress, and Screenplay.  They don't just GIVE those away, no matter what anyone says!This movie is too much fun, and even though the trend lately is to remake older, classic films, this one cannot be improved upon.  However little I knew about Clark Gable or Claudette Colbert before the film, it didn't matter.  I bought the characters, I believed the characters and more than likely, so will you.10/10.

No matter how many times we watch, It Happened One Night ranks as entertainment at its finest! At the time the film was made, kids idealized Hollywood stars. They knew they could never measure up to the level of the stars' perfection! Now, so many years later, Hollywood publicists work overtime to burst our bubbles of yesteryears' perfection! They reduce the long-departed greats to sleeze but why, so long after their passing! Macy and Barbara Ahigian

reviews.review_title: The romantic comedy that won the Oscar podium
reviews.content: As part of my acquaintance with the Academy Award winners, I managed to watch an interesting, but rather predictable film "It Happened one Night" in 1934. The film collected five awards at once, including the Best film and the Best male and female roles. An illustrative aspect, however, after watching it, I was not delighted either with the performance of the main actors or with the picture itself. I wouldn't call the movie bad, but I didn't really like it.The picture will demonstrate a fairly formulaic plot for our time, where a rich girl runs away from piled-up problems and gets acquainted with a little lucky journalist who is in search of really worthwhile material, which will certainly help to improve the position of a man. The main characters are played by Claudette Colbert and Clark Gable. Both are good in their roles, convincing, but it still seems to me that the couple got their Oscars only because there were no alternatives. I would not call their game outstanding.History is another matter. Even if it sometimes looks ridiculous and even affected, it cannot be taken away from the fact that it was this picture that gave rise to a whole direction of films, which is now commonly called roadmuvi. "It happened one night" in a peculiar way plays out various interesting moments that happen to the characters during their journey. The audience will then be able to see the same elements in many similar paintings, and an attentive moviegoer will surely understand that they were inspired by this Oscar-winning picture.Despite my reserved attitude to this work, I in no way detract from its merits to world cinema, on the contrary, I see in the film a lot of things that changed the aesthetics of cinema and inspired new paintings by other authors who successfully borrowed the concept of this film or its elements. The film came out average, not claiming to be a masterpiece, but it should not be forgotten that I, as a viewer of the 21st century, had already seen a lot of paintings before I got to this work. And that's why the film seemed like a kind of gray horse, a picture that you would hardly want to review again.5 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: A good pairing of Gable and Colbert
reviews.content: This movie has the same basic premise of Roman Holiday with the starving news reporter looking for a story and a runaway rich girl falling into his lap, and into his heart.  It Happened...doesn't have the beautiful sights of Rome, but makes up for it with the dazzling banter between Gable and Colbert.  Colbert was an outstanding pre-Code Hollywood actress, and this movie, though it was made after the code was in place, shows some of the same vivacity she had in those earlier films which would later fade.  This is a classic that any movie buff shouldn't do without.  People praise Frank Capra for It's a Wonderful Life, and that praise is even more validated with this shorter, spunkier comedy.

I found the side characters provided most of the comedy but the 2 leads were fun to watch too. I particularly enjoyed their early banter, more as equals, but less enjoyable as her character gradually lost her edge as she became more reliant on him. It is essentially a road trip movie and it felt fast paced and energetic as their journey flipped from one mode of transport to the next, the singing chauffeur being a hilarious highlight. Being the 1930s there are obviously going to be jarring moments here and there but I was pleasantly surprised at her father's progressive and almost empowering attitude by the end, which seemed out of place for the era.

Probably the best romantic comedy movie I've seen. Basically, a spoiled heiress runs away from her father and meets a down-and-out newspaper reporter, and together they travel across the united states. Lots of elements in this movie are surprisingly well-done for a movie from the 30s. The soundtrack is pleasant, and doesn't blow out my ears with trumpets or strings. The acting is a little campy-early-movie, but again it doesn't take me out of it. Many of the scenarios (the singing driver, the song on the bus, the fake-hitman scene) actually had me laughing 90 years after its release. Even a few of the camera shots (the tracking ones) were impressive. Some of the editing wasn't great, but that's a product of the time. Overall, a fun rom-com.

Unlike most pictures, this one is still sometimes shown on TV. Why - because it's not just us old movie fans who love this, everyone can enjoy it.Besides being the epitome of the thirties: everything is there: a hard-boiled newspaper man, a spoilt socialite, 30s dialogue, gangster references and old New York to boot, it has a remarkably fresh feel. There's absolutely nothing about this which a modern film maker would do differently. The style of acting, the direction, the editing, the score are all perfect.Although the Frank Capra/Robert Riskin partnership is often remembered for their slightly later 'social commentary, little man against the world comedy dramas, this in my opinion is their crowing glory (I'm obviously excluding IT'S A WONERFUL LIFE of course since that is the best film ever!) Having unjustly not won the Oscar for their boss Harry Cohn the previous year with LADY FOR A DAY, the pair made sure they would this time by poaching the era's biggest stars, putting them in a wonderfully feel-good story and having them act like nobody has ever acted before.Although Claudette Colbert didn't want to make this, she is wonderful in this. Just look at she acts with her eyes when Clarke Gable is talking to her. I don't think I've ever seen this before - you can literally watch her falling in love. The whole thing is magical.

Ellen escapes from father and on her quest to New York encounters Peter, a recently fired newspaper reporter and slowly falls in love with him. Firstly being repelled by Peter and despising him for his honesty and free talk slowly realizes how he managed to keep her moving. As she constantly goes through troubles on her way to NY he offered his help in exchange for story. After one day has passed her mood was obviously changed onto better and more understanding and loving. Peter also goes through all kind of trouble in helping her which made him care for like no one before. With many twists throughout movie that changed way of movie plot and pushed us in new direction they had to deal with a lot of and find comfort in each other. At the end she run away from her real husband and gave us really incredible ending. Gable as Peter was absolutely great, as he is sincere, but also cares for Elie and finally falls in love.
